name: Killing Floor
description: 6-player co-op survival horror at its finest! Free updates, free special events and a ridiculous amount of fun!
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP/Vista                     Processor: 1.2 GHZ or Equivalent                     Memory: 1 GB RAM                     Graphics: 64 MB DX9 Compliant                     Hard Drive: 2 GB free hard drive space                     Sound: DX 8.1 Compatible Audio
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows XP/Vista                     Processor: 2.4 GHZ or Equivalent                     Memory: 2 GB RAM                     Graphics: 128 MB DX9 Compliant with PS 2.0 support                     Hard Drive: 2 GB free hard drive space                     Sound: Eax Compatible

reviews.review_text: Absolutely the best co-op survival horror game. With a very good amount of achievements, maps, weapons and enemies. Great game to play with friends. I strongly advise to buy it, this game will give you thousands of hours of fun.

Brief summary: Pros:  +Easy to jump into and have fun  +Should be able to run on the majority of Computers  +Huge amounts of replayability  +Workshop support ensures you can always try a new map or mutator out  The game's harder difficulties provide a real challenge to the hardcore  Most of the DLC is purely cosmetic  +The game is frequently updated with newer weapons (This might not happen anymore   as kf2 comes closer)  +Has a SDK if you want to use that.   Cons:  Some of the perks you can use aren't as useful as others  The hitboxes can become a pain at times  Some mechanics aren't explained at all  At times, the community can be bad(They're a minority)  Recent DLCs lock some more useful weapons away. Not too big of an issue though  Server browser is a bit annoying at times   //Long version//  Killing floor is co operative first person shooter where up to six british men can exterminate zeds,an experiment gone wrong.(There are are also a few women and a robot)   Graphics: Killing floor's graphics are decent and the art style of some maps in particular are amazing, and give out its atmosphere well. Don't expect anything spectacular though.  This game should be able to run on most older pcs just fine if you lower the graphics a lot and your resolution. Any good pc should run this with no worries.  This game caters to both casual and hardcore players. The objective is simple, kill all the enemies. It's easy to jump in and understand that you should probably kill all the guys trying to rip you apart. for those who play the game more often, the game can get really intense on the harder difficulties, where an understanding of each zeds mechanics is required to succeed.  Since this is a team based game, having friends along can make the experience much more better. Although if you're a solo player like me, the game is still a ton of fun, just a lot more fun with friends. Every enemy in this game feels unique, from the basic waddling clot to that guy with a chainsaw for an arm. Each enemy acts differently, and each have characteristics that separate them from the others.  The maps in this game are of a wide variety. Some take place in urban environments, some in factories, others in fictional lands. With the workshop, you can find countless more community maps.  The voice acting of this game is both a positive and a negative. It is humorous at first, but when you start playing a lot, it gets incredibly repetitive.  The majority of the DLC for this game is cosmetic, skins for your character or a camo for you weapon. There are a few DLCs which give you new weapons. none of them are completely overpowered but some contain useful weapons. I recommend buying these DLCs first.  At its price, killing floor is absolutely worth it. It also frequently goes on sale, so grab it during then if  you're unsure.  // Review end // I rewrote this because i noticed it had become popular, I updated the horrible formatting because it was not easy to read. I cleaned up a lot of the content and added a brief summary. Hopefully this helped

After reviewing the (crap) sequel I feel oblidged to review this masterpiece.  This game came out at the time when the devs still boasted about being modders. Great. This game was fantastic and even though it was not Early Access, the devs kept updating it, and kept releasing amazing free content including some fantastic DLC. Steampunk Weapons Pack and Community Weapons Pack are pretty much essential and I was willing to pay that money because the devs more than deserved it.   This game has easily the best firearms ever made for a video game, the sound design is stunning, the satisfaction from killing enemies by a headshot in zed-time is OVER 9000.. There is very little I can criticise this game for, because of how much fun I've had with it over the years.   However it is not a a game that will be loved by everyone. It is hardcore in the best sense of the word, there is no melee attack besides the knife, there is no sprint button, the guns have massive recoil, unless you are using the appropriate perk. The levelling up can take weeks, but it is worth hitting that golden star. As a certified addict, even now, 7 years after the release I will still jump into the game every so often to snipe some heads with the Steampunk Musket <3  9/10  *Ignore the sequel*

Overall Rating: 9.9/10  Review of the main aspects of the game:  Controls 10/10 Graphics- 9/10 (considering this game started as a mod on a game ~10 years ago) Teamplay- 10/10 The weapons 9/10 (could have more variety, but well balanced) Level system 10/10 Balance of the Zeds (enemies)- 9.5/10 (still die inside when 5 sirens spawn behind 2 fleshpounds, and 3 scrakes) Mods- 10/10 (Plenty of mods for reskins, more guns, more maps, even making money a weapon.)  Background information about the game for those who want to buy it: You, and up to 5 others if you want, are sent into a living hell fighting off zeds, human experiments that have been cloned by the thousands by Horzine as 'soldiers', in the good ol' queen's country of England. The zeds include clots, bloats, gorefasts, stalkers, sirens, crawlers, husks, Scrakes (SC), and Fleshpounds (FP). You have to stay alive for 10 waves of these horrible creatures that slowly gets progressively worse with/ as a bunch of psychopaths. Until the end of each round where you trade with a... horny? perverted? trader who will take dosh you earn from killing zeds (bounty) to give you more guns. HOWEVER! You can only carry 15kg of equipment (it increases if you're a support). There are 7 balanced classes in the game as follows: Field Medic, Support Specialist, Sharpshooter, Commando, Berserker, Firebug, and Demolitions. Finally, surviving all 10 waves you then have to fight the patriarch an evil clone of Horzine's CEO along with some lower class zeds. Killing Floor features 5 difficulties (Beginner, Normal, Hard, Suicidal, [HoE] Hell on Earth). These difficulties are built for higher leveled perks in correlation.  My personal thoughts about KF: So I've just clocked in over 300 hours and have started to get comfortable on suicidal difficulty. So i figured it was time to rewrite my cheesy review and do a serious review for, what is now one of my favorite PC titles, Killing Floor. I got this game around a year ago after i got a steam account for ~$5 and immediately fell in love with the charm this game has. Between the cheap one liners, slow motion decapitation, and heavy metal rifts. Also the leveling is very addicting at first, even when you're grinding for stalkers as a commando. However, i was just scratching the surface of this game. Although it has a great controls for a zombie co-op game, addicting leveling, and loads of teamwork on harder difficulties. The one thing not a lot of reviews talk about is the learning curve to this game, and how well situated it feels as you level up your perks you slowly learn more and more tricks and tactics in the game that help you survive until you finally get up to Suicidal/ HoE servers with 6 man teams. Killing Floor is so well-built compared to most games that start out as mods and has such depth to it that allows you to have fun even after you've played West London 100+ times and you're still not done with it. Not to mention how no matter how many times you successfully 1v1 a fleshpound as a bezerker, uppercut a scrake as a support, etc. you still feel like a bonafide badass. All in all, this game is worth every penny even if it isn't on sale, or was $60 dollars currently. Why? Because this game grows on you and will give you hours and hours of entertainment as you go from dying on normal due to 1 or 2 sirens to taking down the patriarch on HoE.  Summary?: This game is great, no matter if you only want to put 10 hours into it, or hundreds upon thousands of hours into it.
why are you reading this when you could be slaying those ugly creatures?   One of the best co-op games I have ever played! If you like/liked left4dead2 then you gonna love that one!  10/10

Now that the sequel has been announced I figured I'd write a review for what is perhaps my most favorite game of the past few years.  Killing Floor is a brilliant FPS survival horror, and perhaps the best (At least in my opinion) wave-based game out there. The game has a balance of gritty and serious environments and witty and morbid humor. The idea that you are working your way through a horde of genetically engineered monsters to finally go toe-to-toe with the final boss gives you that sense of achievement. And going toe-to-toe with the final boss is an achievement in itself; with traits from all other specimen  combined  and then some, you'll need a lot of bullets.  A key aspect of Killing Floor is co-op. with seven different perks to play as that fill different roles in a team, you're gonna have a hard time doing it alone. Synergy with other players is key; you could just as easily doom another player as opposed to helping them. There is a lot more to the game than it seems at first glance. All of the specimen have different nuances and behavioral quirks that you will need to learn to survive. Fortunately the Beginner mode is very forgiving so you have plenty of opportunity to get some practice in. However, the difficulty curve is like a brick wall; it's not uncommon for even veteran players to fall to the horde on even the lower difficulties.  The game is very community-driven. There are a lot of custom content for the game which is fully supported, and even some of the DLC and updates are filled with community-created content. You can expect new maps, weapons, enemies, characters, game modes and mutators.  Despite being an old game it still looks beautiful and has an incredible soundtrack. There is plenty of content for this game and the only people I wouldn't suggest this game to are the squeamish.
15/10  easy quick to join a multiplayer or start a solo mission challenging achievements no lag no glitches runs smoothly very helpful and friendly community

Do i recommend Killing Floor? Hell yeah! Starting out in KF was daunting for me, since i rarely play FPS games and my only previous experience was in Counter strike. To top it off, i found that i didn't have on-screen crosshairs!  Needless to say, the first couple hours of playing this game usually resulted in me dying rather quickly to simple enemies like clots and gorefasts. Damn those buggers are fast..  As i continued playing the game, i learned about ammo conservation, and how to make shots count. On lower difficulties you don't really need to worry about ammo too much - unless you're demolitions and shoot off a grenade at anything that moves. On harder difficulties though, you really need to make your shots count, since there are more enemies, they take more shots to kill and you get less reward money for killing stuff.  I have bought this game as a gift for several friends and had a absolute blast playing it.  Grab it on sale or something, its really cheap and there's really no excuse why you can't afford it.  One of the best purchases i made on steam.

Killing Floor is a fantastic family game, which combines aspects of team building, puzzle solving, and perception. It will surely give you hours, or maybe even days of fun. When you start the game, you have the option to play by yourself or cooperative. Since this is a family game, playing solo is not recommended as it will not give you the full experience of Killing Floor. The co-op games can have up to 6 players, that means you, your brother or sister, your parents, maybe your favorite grandparents and your pet warthog. The goal is simple: Have as much fun as possible! You and your teammates will be put in classic maps like kf_abusementpark and kf_hellride. Before you can play, you will have to select a so called ''perk''. It is recommended that all players play field medic, because their special funbombs have a lovely green glow when thrown, but I'll come to that later. After everyone clicked on 'ready up' you will spawn in the chosen map. Take a moment to look around in these beautiful places, because there are many things to be seen. I myself have found a sleeping horse, a dancing robot, a man with a television head, and a mini caravan. Soon you will realize that you are in fact, holding a gun. This is a glitch that should be fixed by the developers, because people might get a wrong idea from what this game is about. It is recommended that you press '5' to switch to your love dispenser. Soon you will hear the joyful cheers of the npcs in this game. There is the Clot, a little elf that will hug you *with force*, the delicious Gingerbreadman, the beautifully constructed snowman called ''Husk'', the Siren (who will sing for you) , Rudolph the crawling reindeer, the Scrake (I think he's made out of ice cream :3), the Bloat (Santa Claus), the Patriarch (Bigger Santa) When these npcs hug your or give you colorful flying thingies, your screen will get red from ketchup, it is really fun! Oh and.. ahem.. the Stalker. I'd like the developers to delete this npc, as it is inappropriately clothed. It does NOT belong in a family game like Killing Floor. I hope it is just a bug like the guns and other weapons in this game.   Overall this game is fun, and you (or a family member) should defenitly get it, but the developers should really fix the various bugs in this game.   pi/5 would play again.

Initially a very two dimensional game that while fun, lacked proper staying power, Killing Floor has grown as it's gone on.  The seasonal events and the relatively recent addition of a campaign have helped keep the game from stagnating and kept people obsessed with achievements coming back.  Not really a fan of their more recent DLC, adding weapons that tip the balance to favour players who buy DLC is not something I can agree with.  The game is only truly fun when you're playing with people who know their stuff, and who communicate and coordinate with one another. Friends with microphones and reasonable Internet connections are what you need to make this game really work out well.  With the afore mentioned companions, it can be a fun game to throw yourself into from time to time, though a less tactical one than Left4Dead.

Experimentin' stuff has gone bad. Crazy experiments are on the loose. Whole cities are abandoned (or all inhabitants are exterminated, but hey, no one had time to inform you about that!). No one knows where you are, but as a cold comfort: most people don't even care whether or not you survive, so even if they could, they wouldn't help you. You and your squad are on your own, surrounded by experiments and weird humanoid-looking-ish fusions that are basically your worst nightmare, and theyre out there to eat you. Exterminate them all or they will have you grilled medium rare for dinner. AND AS IF THAT WASN'T BAD ENOUGH YET, once you destroyed enough experiments, the creator and 'father' of them will appear, and he wont be happy! But who could blame him? You'd be mad too if a random squad of 6 weirdos would come and kill hundreds and hundreds of your children! This is the premise of Killing Floor, a first person shooter that brings you to a (maybe not so original, but who cares, as long as you can shoot things) scenario in which you're the last men standing against monstrous opponents. With a good variety of enemies and five difficulty levels, this game is gamer-friendly for the newbiest of newbies and challenging for the experienced exterminator, whereas every different enemy will require a different strategy to get rid of when you play on the highest difficulty level. You will level up your classes on the go to match your characters abilities with the level you'll be playing on. With the 7 different playable classes (or Perks) you can play your preferred role in a team, so you'll have your favourite way of destroying evil: Fightin' (or kitin') like a MAN? play Berzerker. Steady aim, ready to take out the big threats? play Sharpshooter. Do you like to watch the world burn? play Firebug. Like gibs flyin' around and explosions? play Demolitions. Assault rifles 'n kalashnikovs 'n stuff? play Commando. Wanna be that guy that carries a million different (and heavy) guns? play Supports specialist. Do you love ze healing, not ze hurting? play Field medic!  This all comes with a sh*tload of different maps in completely different settings (woods, buildings, cities, north pole, on a ship, on the moon, EVERYWHERE), able to keep your interest for quite a while. Also contains objective modes to keep the diversity in the game.  STILL haven't had enough? There's an incredible amount of custom content with EVEN MORE perks to level up to even greater heights, additional objective modes with a wide range of different goals to achieve.  To top this off, your squad consists of whiny, cocky british people with a strong accent, so insults, directions and calls for help will sound hilarious! Despite many negative remarks on the 'crappy' voice acting, I actually think the lack of seriousness these squad members show with their snarky voice commands adds nicely to the game's attractiveness.  Pros: - A million different guns - Dont like guns? It has explosives too - AND fire - AND melee weapons - Playable at all skill levels - A lot of variety in the maps - Challenging and interesting action on higher levels (especially as berzerker in my opinion) - Enemies with chainsaws - A boss with a machine gun for an arm - ^I forgot to mention his OTHER arm is a FRIGGIN' ROCKET LAUNCHER - Has nice skin overrides with christmas, halloween and in the summer. - 'Help me or I'll be pushin' up the bloody daisies!'  Cons - By far not the best graphics (Don't get me wrong, they're not terrible!) - Camping to survive waves on high difficulty can get stale easily (but there's kiting to make up for that) - Not the most serious and realistic shooter (I personally don't mind, but I know many will see this as a downside)  'YOU MURDERED MY CHILDREN': prepare to fight, stock up on the biggest, baddest guns and bombs and sht and take the challenge! A great gore-spattered shooter that will be guaranteed entertainment for a long time!  Rating: 9/10

Killing Floor is a co-op game, where you can play alone, about experiments gone wrong and invading London (and the world too as seen in KF2 and as seen on some KF maps). Your goal is to survive 4,7 or 10 waves of enemies, while earning money by killing them (or by healing your teammates) so that you can buy powerful weapons during the minute of calm at the trader between the waves. After, you'll have to defeat the Patriarch, who is the sole responsible for the chaos. You can choose different difficulties: Easy (which is really to learn the game), Normal, Hard, Suicidal and Hell on Earth.  Enemies are thougher depending on the difficulty but you too can evolve and acquire advantages like spawning with a better weapon than a pistol or armor thanks to the level system. You have 6 of them and it takes time. However, you have different classes: medic (no powerful weapon but more resistance and better health), commando (rifles and can see stalkers from apart), support (big guns and better welder), demo (everything that is explosive), berserker (melee and also can't be grabbed), sharpshooter (sniper and headshots more efficient) and firebug (flame everywhere).  Enemies are varied: from the simple Zed to the infamous Fleshpound that can kill you quickly, without forgetting the Scrake and the chainsaw, the Gorefast that cuts you in pieces, the Crawler that loves your feet, the Stalker who is hidden, the Husk that launches fireballs, the Siren that is hurting your ears (and your health)....  Anyway, the game in its actual state contains many maps (some are official, others done by modders) and mutators with Christmas-themed or Halloween-Themed or Circus-Themed enemies (because they were parts of special events). The maps are very varied: fair, tunnel of love, Santa's workshop or cave, asylum, Horzine labs, urban town, mountain, hospital, etc..  But you'll ask me: what about the DLC? Well, all the DLC are cosmetic. True, you have new weapons in them and they can be used for achievements. However, you can do them with the standard weapons, that are enough like the AA12 for example. And you can unlock avatars by playing with themed mutators for example or owning other games. And that's how you own two Mr Foster (the normal and the steampunk).  Killing Floor in solo holds interest if you want to level without having a team to check or to win map achievements in Normal/Hard. An higher difficulty is better with a team, however, keep in mind that some of the players aren't using the perks for the team but for themselves. I've seen many medics choosing this perk for the advantages it's giving in terms of resistance or health but not healing at all the team for example. It's annoying as hell and if I seems to be upset by this kind of behavior, it's because I'm a medic first in this game, because I feel more useful by healing my teammates than beginning to put pipe bombs, welding the right doors or being a specialist of the crossbow. Healing is important in that game and if a medic is there, he's more powerful for the heal than the rest of the team. Not using of that fact can result in premature death on high difficulty.  Anyway, with Killing Floor 2, I don't know if there are still a lot of players there. I still need to win Suicidal and Hell on Earth achievements, as I've all Hard and Normal and that all my perks are lvl5+. But it's still worthy to play. As long as there are servers and as long as the solo mode is there, Killing Floor is really a very strong co-op game. However, make sure that you're not discouraged when level 0. By patience, by learning and by leveling, you'll find more and more pleasure to survive these waves.

Killing Floor is one of the greatest cooperative game to ever come out on Steam. Is it really? Definitely. Since the game was debut in 2009, Killing Floor evolved with many seasonal events, free weapons and maps, and small cosmetic downloadable content to support Tripwire Interactive's longevity to Killing Floor. One would ask: What is Killing Floor? Well, Killing Floor is a six player multiplayer cooperative survival game that takes on against various 'zeds', ranging from the clots to the rage-meter Fleshpound that will grind your body into giblets. There are seven perks that you can select that varies from the Support Specialist with its ultimate shotgun barrage to the fast running Berserker that you will probably become the 'ultimate ninja' if you play long enough (Berserker is my favorite perk to use; it's really fun). The game may become a bit repetitious, but the maps, playing with your friends, or meeting (and making friends) with other players in the Killing Floor community will make you come back and enjoy killing those zeds.   Did I mention zed time (or slow motion)? There is and seeing zeds being decimated is an appeal to the eyes. The last question remains: Do you have this game in your Steam library? If not, go get this game..now! If you already have KF, go join in a server and have fun. For those who are waiting for Killing Floor 2, I will see you there when it comes out on Day One. Get this game and enjoy it as much as you can before the Patriarch attacks again in Killing Floor 2.
if you like violence and massacre mutants this game is right for you

Killing Floor: Come for the fancy accents, Stay because of the serious addiction. 10/10

I know KF2 is out soon but i had to write this just to hail this astonishment called Killing Floor! I played it nearly 500 hours and sometimes still coming back just to have a good hour. I'm a hardcore singleplayer guy, avoid MP as pest and guess what, this is the only multiplayer game i played continously in the recent years. No matter how experienced i am after 500 hours if i'm not carefull enough even the singlest Clot can kill me. This everyday challenge, the weird-scary enemies and level design, the parodical amount of gore, the unbelievable good weapon system and the actual weapons and the teamwork is what makes this game one of the best games ever, and for me, the absolutely king of the multiplayer FPS genre.

Killing Floor is an intense RPG/FPS that can take minutes to get into but hundreds of hours to become proficient at. The game offers 5 difficulties, the lower of which you can be comfortable playing alone but the higher difficulties demand exceptional teamwork in order to overcome the grisly odds. Seven different perks that grow in power as you level them up to six times allow you to choose the type of destruction you wish to bring to the mutant freaks.  The combat includes anywhere from one to six players and the more people you have on your squad the larger the force and the bigger the healthpool of the opposition. The menace you attempt to best with your buddies is as diverse as they are deadly. Wave-based gameplay gradually introduces you to the specimens while giving you time to save up your dosh for spending at the games rather formidable armory.   While the game is four years old the developers still release brand new content for the game on a semi-regular basis, with seasonal updates that reskin the specimens you fight into hilariously creepy incarnations. New characters, new weapons and new maps await even the veteran players every few months.

Killing Floor tells the story of Booker T. DeWitt, a private detective hired to investigate the kidnapping of Dosh by an ancient race of sentient machines known as 'The Reapers'. The 'Reapers' live underground and use emergence holes to access the world above. Aided by his old friend Victor Sullivan they must retrieve an item known as the Cintamani Stone in order to fight an invasion by a terrifying parasitic alien horde known as The Flood.  The game Stars Bill Cosby as the voice of The Fleshpund and a musical score by Michael Buble and performances by the cast of smash hit broadway musical 'Cats'. Killing Floor is a quirky, indie romp with a fantastic performance from Ellen Page as Mr. Fosters love interest. I heartily recommend this game to anyone who loves 2d sidesrolling platformers

31 March ,year 2014.A very good friend of mine,asked me what game i would like to play:Borderlands 1 or Killing Floor.I did not had any idea what games those were...so i decided to take Killing FLoor,because it sounded awesome.And i was not wrong ;) Killing Floor is a coop game at it's best.You can also play it solo ,offline,but the coop is where all the fun is present.It features unique classes called perks,which all have their 'job'.Of course you can experiment,but you need to know a few things about a certain perk in order to play the game right.Don't worry,the community is nice and they won't destroy you because you are new to the game....unless you joined an suicidal or hell on earth server.Suicidal and Hell on Earth are the hardest difficulties in this game.So,if you are a beginner....better to play firstly normal difficulty servers.Don't play beginner,unless you are new to the FPS genre. The mechanics in the game are well implemented.For instance,if you play as a commando,you can either play only using assault rifles (which is commando's main job) or you can experiment with other weapons,since one of the special abillities that you get as a commando is the fact that you can reload ALL weapons with a fast speed! Yes,the perks/classes have all their own special abilities which makes them so unique/useful in certain situations.For instance, the Sharpshooter is usually the best perk for dealing with big enemies,because of his powerful weapons.However,he isn't that much useful when comfronting many smaller enemies...of course if you are skilled at sharpshooting,you won't have any problem,but you need to know your prioroties and not just shoot everyone or steal the kills (Yes Fetch i'm looking at you :D). Now,the enemies are called ZEDS.Not zombies-zeds.Cloned experiments that went wrong.Basically.There are not so many types of them,but their 'abillities' make up for it.They were (And are!) so well designed,that you will very very very hard get bored from them.I do not want to spoil to much,but they are a bit cliche,but still original on their own :) Guns.Very good.Sounds are well done.Also,some DLC's give you weapons which you can not normally buy from the trader (using ingame money that you get for killing enemies NOT REAL LIFE MONEY-real money you use for bying dlc's),but if a player owns a DLC he can drop t hat weapon to you and you can use it! Also,the DLC's weapons are very strong and useful,but even with the stock weapons you can be a real pro in games if you trained enough. In the end, Killing Floor,that originally started as a mod back in 2005,turns out to be one of the best Indie coop shooting horror games.It is fun,challenging,DLC's system is fair,community is nice (almost on every server) but in order to enjoy it the most,you will have to learn a lot of stuff.Of course you can have some fun without paying to much attention to t he game,but in that case,you will miss way to many things.IT also supports workshops,has huge variety of maps,achieviements,etc. and because it is from 2009,that doesn't mean that the game is not populated.Of course,player base suffered a major drop because of Killing Floor 2 (which is also great by the way),but if you buy this game,you will not be dissatisfied :) Thank you for reading my review.Have a nice day! Alright, even though this game was made in '09, has graphics that would make make a grandmother have a stroke, AI that, in comparison to other games that were released in the same time frame, were clunky and irrational most of the time. Also included is a server browser system that has been known to drive people to insanity.  Few games have given me more enjoyment than Killing Floor.  The game is very simplistic in its objective: See zombie, shoot zombie, get paid, buy bigger guns, repeat. Even though this may seem boring while you sit there, in your 'gaming chair', waiting for your next game of Dota 2 to load, it really isn't. There is nothing more enjoyable and suspenceful than playing with a group of 5 friends (the game allows 6 people in standard servers), everyone dying but you on wave 10 on suicidal, out of ammo against 2 fleshpunds and about 30 other Zeds.  The gameplay is very enjoyable, especially on higher difficulties, like suicidal or HoE (Hell on Earth), where teamwork is absolutely essential for survival for all 10 waves. There are 7 perks, each has its own ablilities (like the Berzerker, which does bonus melee damage) and uses for helping your squad survive the onslaught of horrific freaks you're up against. The maps are varied and requie you to shose your perks accordingly, depending on if its a day or night map, or open space or tight corridors. The goal of Killing Floor is to survie all 10 waves to get to wave 11, which is the main freak leader himself: the Patriarch. If you kill him (no mercy allowed), your squad survives. If all of you die in the course of 1 round, you lose. At the end of each round, any dead players respawn, but only if there are still surviving players.  Tripwire has done a very good job of keeping players in the game durring its 5 years of release. They have done special events, such as The Twisted Christmas Event, or Hillbilly Horror (Halloween). Also, a steady drip of new maps, characters, and guns have fallen into the hands of eagerly awaiting fans, most of which are given freely, or in-game achievement unlocks. Even though there are several packs of guns only available through paid DLC, they do not affect game ballance in the least, but only serve to vary gameplay and team tactics. Also included is the complete is a very extensive set of od tools, allowing useres to create vurtually anything they want with the game; now that Killing Floor has Workshop, a hwole new relm of content has been opend to players.  Over all, this game has kept me satified for over a year, as well as Tripwire gaining my respect for thier devotion to their playerbase. Alright Tripwire, time to bring Killing Floor 2 to the eagerly awating masses.

Killing Floor is a multiplayer co-op zombie shoot em up game that requires lots of skill. I will break down the review in the sections below or you can read the conclusion at the end if you don't want to read the whole thing.   Gameplay:  There are two modes, the Killing Floor mode where you simply survive each round and the Objective mode where you have to fulfill certain missions. Only few maps have the Objective mode though. What makes this game hard are the gameplay mechanics, there is no crosshair and it is VERY easy to die if your team does not communicate strategy.  It goes without saying that the learning curve for this game can be higher than your run-of-the-mill fps, you need to learn how to use each class for which situation and memorize the maps by heart in order to survive in higher difficulties. Basically the game has seven classes, each with their merits and disadvantages ranging from melee to pyro to sharshpooting specialists and more.  You fight zombies in waves, a the end of each round you are able to use the shop to purchase armor, ammo, and weapons using the money that you collected after killing the zombies. Depending on the difficulty you start with 300 pounds if you are playing on easy, 250 pounds if on medium and so on. There are many weapons to choose from, ranging from regular guns to flamethrower to katana and chainsaw. The vanilla game contains large amount of maps both in open areas and closed areas, you can also download new maps from the workshop as well.    Graphics:  I will not be critical in this point, the game is from 2009 and originally it was a mod, so do not expect something of high quality. However it is easy to max it out at 60 fps even if you got an older machine (mine is AMD 4670, Dual-Core E5400 2.7GHz). Even though the detail is low, the graphics look clean enough and they do not distort from the experience, you will hardly notice them in the middle of the action anyway. However slowdowns can occur if you are fighting many zombies at once.   Sound:  The sounds in the game are average at best, the guns lack impact, the explosions don't sound good. But the monster sounds are very well executed. Again, you will hardly notice this anyway.   Online Community:  The online community is a hit or miss, I highly recommend that you play this game with a friend if possible because you will die a LOT if you play with strangers. Many players act like noobs and run by themselves to die at the end and never heal you or give you money when you need it. Thankfully though, in higher difficulties the community tends to be better because you really cannot survive if you play on your own so you are forced to cooperate with others and play strategically and communicate with your teammates.    Conclusion:  Killing Floor gives a new perspective to co-op zombie shooters, it is a real co-op game where if you don't play as a team you will fail. The various classes and the weapon and map choices will keep you busy for plenty of hours, each map requires its own survival strategy. Winning a fight gives you a great sense of satisfaction as you will die a lot. The only realy con I can find in this game is that you will end up with noobs more often than not if you want to chill in the lower difficulties. If you are a fan of co-op shooters of any kind, buy this game immediately, beware though it is very addictive.

Killing Floor is one of the funnest games on Steam.  I first played Killing Floor on a coworker's PC (Windows 7) ALOT, and recently played it on my laptop (Linux Mint 17.3 64 bit).  PROS: + Fun and frantic wave-based FPS action. + Co-op mode stands shoulder-to-shoulder with L4D2. + COD-like weapon load outs with the ability to trade off between waves. + Tactical, squad based combat. Pick your class and be ready to aid your teammates in battle. + Modest hardware requirements. Played KF on a ThinkPad T410 with Nvidia 3100M graphics and it runs smooth. + Windows, Mac, and Linux versions all included. + A steal at $20 and often on sale for far less.  CONS: None that I can think of. The only microtransactions are for cosmetic stuff, a'la TF2.

Killing Floor is a first-person survival horror horde game with two different game modes. In the classic Killing Floor game mode you have to defend you and your team from several waves of varying types of zombies and defeat the final boss at the end. In Objective mode you have to complete a set of objectives while defending yourself and your team from waves of zombies and then defeat a final boss at the end... I've only just realised how familiar they sound. There are seven classes to choose from, which consist of your generic healer, shotguner, marksman, assault rifler, beserker, pyro and demolitions.  So, first of all, let's get one thing clear: Yes, that's all you do. I've heard criticism from a number of people sdtating that Killing Floor seems to be extremely repetetive. And yes, it is, but the game is so fun that it doesn't matter. I could argue that deathmatch on 'insert generic shooter here' is repetetive since all that consists of is running around and getting shot, and yet that's still fun!  But before I praise the game for what it does well, let's clear up on what it does badly: The voice acting is awful, but is still corny and funny. Hearing the pyro from Team Fortress 2 calling someone a 'plod' in a cockney accent thicker than paint is hilarious. The game looks dated, but that's no surprise considering it's running on Unreal 2.5; having said that it still looks like a really good PS2 game, so it's bearable. A few of the zombie types are a bit overpowered, such as the Siren, who's screams have a range longer than they look, ignore armour and shake your screen to the point where it's impossible to make anything out. The Patriarch's chain gun seems to deal a little too much damage, even for the final boss. And the Skrake has way too much health.  But what is the game good for? For starters, this game has some of the best use of classes I have seen. Each class has subtle yet effective buffs to their use in weapons, with the more noticeable ones being discounts for their weapons types, and spawning with a free class specific gun when that class level is really high. Every class can equip every weapon, and every class can be upgraded regardless of which one you're playing as, which is great. The guns are SO satisfying to use, and I really recommend buying the weapons DLC packs. At the very least, if you're only going to buy one, I recommend the Steampunk one. They are some of the most interesting guns I have seen in a game, and they are guns used in the more popular classes. What makes the guns so satisfying? The high, yet affordable costs, the size, the models, the recoil, the gorgeous sounds, the power, even the reload animations come together to create such amazing toys that are simply a joy to use. The maps are all different and really well made, even though a few too many are rather grey and brown, though to be honest, if I were modelling London, I couldn't have done it any other way. The zombie types are interesting and threatening in their own way, with each one possessing an ability that synergises well with all other zombie powers. Even the weakest variation, the Clots, you will learn to hate because of their grab ability that really screws with you when you're trying to backpedal away from a Fleshpound. If there are any two zombies alike, its the Skrake and Fleshpound, but apart from that, they're all different. And this game is a joy to play with friends. Do not get this game unless you have someone to play it with, it is great. And when you buy Killing Floor, you get two coupons to give to friends that allow them a limited time access to it so they can try it!  One last recommendation: Killing Floor is one of those regular sale products on Steam, so wait until its on an inevitable sale, and I don't think a year has gone by when it hasn't been on sale at Christmas. Simply put, buy Killing Floor.

Killing Floor is without a doubt one of the best co-op shooters I have ever played. Don't let the 2009 graphics put you off - this game is still fresh and fun several years later. As of 2013, Tripwire Interactive (the developer of KF) is still providing regular content updates that help keep the game interesting.  How is the game itself? As I said before, the graphics are somewhat dated, but not to the point of being ugly. The sound design is fantastic. All of the weapons have a unique look and feel to them. The one commonality between all 40-some weapons is that they are all very satisfying to use. Even though some weapons cost more than others, there really aren't any weapons that are flat-out better than others. Every weapon is meant to fulfill a certain role and cater to different play styles.  As of now, there are seven classes or 'perks' in the game. Each perk has its own special abilities and strengths. For example, the Firebug perk gets a incendiary grenades and extra damage with fire-based weapons, while the Medic perk gets healing grenades and more effective heals. No matter what your playstyle is, KF has a perk to accommodate you.  Teamwork is at the core of this game, especially on higher difficulty levels. Generally speaking, if teammates do not support each other, the entire team will fail. The diversity of enemies and map layouts forces teams to be just as diverse. A team that cannot adapt to sudden changes in enemy forces will most likely die horribly.  As you can probably tell by my total play time in this game (365 hours as of this posting) this game has immense replay value. My recommendation to you is to buy this game on sale and play it with some friends. If you enjoy dark, gritty, and intense co-op shooters, you will not be disappointed by Killing Floor.

Killing Floor really is a magnificent beast of a game. There's so many little things about it that I love. The guns feel AMAZING. Something about them is just absolutely spot on. The British dialogue and voice commands are hilarious, me and my buddies have been quoting them off and on through life for a few years now ('Up stairs to bedtime, children', 'Cheers, big ears!', etc.). TripWire is constantly adding more content to the game too, which is great. The more friends you have who are willing to play this with you the better it is, though. I've seen some lackluster reviews in the past and I think this is mostly due to the online experience not being quite as strategic and badass as holding off the hoards with a group of your buddies. Plus, the hardest difficulty is so damned challenging, it's really easy to get hooked trying to beat a map over and over (and you always make it SO close too before those four fleshies spawn in your face on the last wave with 30 zeds left on the clock).
If this game ever comes out with a sequel I will dedicate the rest of my life figuring out how to mate with a video game.

Killing Floor is yet another zombie game. There are so many of these and still developers make more. So what makes Killing Floor stand out?  First, the setting. All levels are in England, and the voice acting is in a London accent which really helps bring that over, with the added bonus of it being hilarious! This could probably change in DLC but I have yet to play with any of that.  Second, the music. All the background music really helps to get the blood pumping and it fits in with the game really well to create the atmosphere. It sounds sort of like Korn but the original music was actually composed by zYnthetic and Dirge. I think Killing Floor is great for fans of Resident Evil or Team Fortress 2 because it is a FPS with zombies. The class selection is called Perks; such as Firebug - similar to Pyro in TF2. I really like how you can level up the perks just by buying and using the weapons suitable for them - for example with Field Medic you level up by healing other players. The maps work by you facing zombie hordes in waves, and at the end of each wave the trader appears for you to buy items with the money you collect in-game, and at the very end of the waves you face the boss: The Patriarch. The most important part of the Killing Floor is that a successful team will be more likely to prevail - without working together then basically you die a lot. Overall, I think it is a fantastic game!

Killing Floor is one of those games where you can play time and time again and it just never gets old. For being a 10 round survival game, one would think it would get old after a few bouts but this cannot be farther from the truth. The amount of teamwork that is called upon to complete the 10 rounds ( plus boss) is unlike most co op games. The random people you often play with and their playing styles keep the game fresh (plus the many perks and guns). There is also a great community on the servers. There aren't many people who die to screw you. Its more like they die becuase 20+ zeds maul them. One of the biggest positives of this game is that they continue to come out with new maps and guns a few times a year (yes this review is in 2014). The maps are given free and the guns and characters are for purchased DLC.   Overall, this game is a must have just to experience what true gaming teamwork is. If you dont have it ... you will not survive.

I've put a lot of time into games like the left 4 dead series and then i saw this game when roosterteeth did a LP on it and at first i was a bit sceptical about it, but then when i saw it on sale this week i decided if i was going to get it, i had better get it now. Best $4.99 i've ever spent on a game to be honest. In fact, i bought 3 copies for friends as well so that alone should show how much i like it.   Maps - Killing Floor has some great maps that give the players a lot of room for movement or kiting which is essential when facing the bigger bosses plus you get the ability to close doors and then weld them shut in order to provide a obstacle for the zeds (zombies).  Trading - You get cash (euros) for each kill and then at the end of each wave you can go to a trader to get more weapons or armor. If you or a friend is low on cash, you can press B to throw some on the floor for someone to pickup. It drops in increments of 50.  Community - So far every match i have been in, the players are very helpful and as a result i've actually made quite a few friends within a few hours of playing. The servers are very populated and there are plenty of them to choose from.  Gun Recoil - Gun recoil in this game is manageable but those who are used to fps games won't have much of a problem with this. However, those who are new to fps games in general are going to have a bit of trouble at the start due to the amount of recoil that some guns have. As you level your perks up the recoil will get better over time.    All in all i love the game and it was well worth the price tag, so stop reading these reviews and get it. NAO!

Positive     Easy to pick up, hard to master    Large selection of classes, maps and weapons    Quality co-op gameplay with many viable strategies you can try as a team    Large amount of community-made maps and mods    Neutral     After multiple patches and the addition of new content post-release I feel the design of the game has been slightly over-complicated. This could instead be seen as added depth though, depending on your viewpoint    Unreal Engine 2.5 - Even at release in 2009 the game performed well on integrated graphics and cheap hardware, but it's 2015 now so if you're looking for cutting edge graphics, look elsewhere    Negative     UI - the general theme of the interface and character art style isn't particularly well executed    XP system is slightly grindy in my opinion    Not worth £14.99 in 2015 - it's a great game, but wait for a sale   There's nothing mind-blowing or subtle about Killing Floor, but it is an enjoyable co-op survival shooter with a ton of content.

It’s a co-op survival horror game. Up to 6 players in online co-op mode, or just you, on your own, playing the Solo mode. The aim - cleanse each area of zombies, in waves, until you get to the last one. The Big One. The Patriarch. Then exterminate him, too. Actually, they aren’t 'zombies'. They are the left-over 'specimens' from a cheap and dirty government program to clone soldier-monsters. The basic ones will just munch on your arm and try to disembowel you. The bigger ones were the first ones they tried arming. Nothing much. Just a chainsaw or a blade for starters. They had just got on to the chain gun and rockets when the government tried to secretly shut down their secret program. But, in the typical way these things go, the program didn’t want to be shut down. The specimens got loose. No-one was left alive to turn off the specimen-cloning equipment. And now they are running amok. Well, some of them are running amok. Others are shambling amok or even jumping amok, but you get the idea. The police were sent in, but that wasn't even a challenge for the specimens. The first army units hadn't been warned what to expect. The screams of its got a bloody chainsaw!' over the radios probably didn’t do much for morale, as whole units were chewed up. Quite literally, in some cases, of course. And now, there is just you. And a few friends. The few survivors from the first police and army units thrown in. Of course, you can’t tell anyone anything, because that would be a breach of the Official Secrets Act 1911, 1920, 1989. And that would be a disciplinary offense. So just get in there and do your bit for Queen and Country. Zombies. Lots of them. Big ones, little ones. Armed and Dangerous.

Killing floor is a survival co-op game where you fight a lot of monsters until you all die or win the match. What makes this game so good is the amount of different infected people to kill, one type goes invisible, there's a guy with a rocket launcher, some guy with iron hands than goes berserker, a few more and the famous Patriarch. There's 2 types of game modes, killing floor which makes you kill X amount of infected per round and objectives asking you to do several stuff around the map like unweld containers in search of the materials to open the path. Also as you survive waves you can use money to buy weapons, armor , grenades and ammo, also to switch between perks if needed which il talk about next. There's a total of 7 classes and as you play with them you upgrade the perk level to obtain several bonuses like more dmg with class weapons, discount on those weapons, mov speed and unique weapon unlocks when you master it, the following classes are , berseker melee specialist, medic with really good smgs than shoot healing needles, commando, support, firebug who gets a really nice flamethrower at max level , sharpshooter and demolitioner , leveling them isn't really that hard it just takes a lot of time to max any of them. The game is extremely difficult unless you got maxed perks don't expect to solo or duo any map even on normal difficulty you will just get swarmed upon. Killing floor, a great Survival Horror Co-op shooter. This is a fun game, but only with others, namely friends who you can Co-operate with through live communcation, because this game is hard. With a large array of enemies coming at you from all corners, the horror is real but you can fight back with an array of different class specilialites with tons of perks and abilities, the guns feel good and there are lots of them, all the maps are great too. Games can last at least 40minutes long on normal diffuculties alone, trying to do anything above normal is like having a having a ♥♥♥♥ing deathwish though.  You see, thats where the flaws of the game come into play, it's TOO HARD, diffuculty in games isn't a bad thing, infact it's rare in today's games, but Killing Floor takes it to a new level, you'll start off on beginner diffuculty, this is easy, really easy. Of course it's easy, it's beginner, so you step it up to Normal, you're going to die and die and die unless you have a very compotent team and a high level, doing diffuculties like 'Hell on earth' and 'suicide' will require hours upon hours of constant grinding on lower diffuculties, thats not so fun.  That brings me to the leveling, it's ♥♥♥♥ed beyond comprehension, there are six, yes, a mere six whole levels for each class, this doesn't seem like a lot right? Oh no...they've stretched it out so you need to grind for ♥♥♥♥ing days to level up and it gets tedious really fast, I'm begging Killing Floor 2 to fix this god awful leveling mechanic.  My final complaint, the end game wave.  While the previous waves consist of a seemingly endless wave of mutant variants attacking you from you all angles, the final boss is always the same. The Patriarch, you fight him alone to start with but he'll summon peions as the fight goes on, once or twice this fight will be fun, but the same enemy, every single time, for every single mission? Personally I'd like to see some variety in later titles with different end bosses for different missions, fighting the patriarch constantly gets old.  All my complaints aside, this is a great game, one of the best FPS survival shooters I've played, like Left4Dead with more variety and less 'A to B' and like Nazi Zombies but again with more variation and just a thousand times better, the horror is actually present too unlike most Surival shooters. Killing Floor goes on sale quite a lot so I reccommend you give it a whirl.

Combining great gun design, from Tripwire Interactive, and an addictive wave-by-wave zombie-style shooter, Killing Floor gives you a run for more than your money. It gives you a great run for the Trader when the wave has ended and a mad rush to whatever player is liberally sprinkling the ground with 'dosh'. With 6 upgradable classes to choose from, you can knock down your moaning enemies one by one as a sniper, in a great big boom as a demolitionist or any which way you choose! When the wave ends, you rush to the Trader (She alternates where she is so you have to check where the hell you are going) and buy better, faster, bigger weapons to blast even better, faster, bigger enemies back to where they came from! 8/10

Killing Floor is probably one of the best multiplayer co-op games out there. With the usual small caveat of 'as long as your team works as a team'. Killing Floor is a VERY team-centric game, and while there may be people out there who boast they can solo maps while leaving their teams in the dust, that just doesn't fly in the higher difficulty settings, where the game really expects you all to pull together and perform your chosen roles.  There's no room for 'let's all go as the same class' a good part of the time. You WILL encounter monsters that are resistant to the damage your class specializes in, and your limited ammo will end up being chewed up way too fast. There's no room for 'I'll just go lone wolf' most of the time, since the game will  happily  spawn groups of monsters on top of anyone who decides to Rambo their way through a stage, ala  Left 4 Dead 1/2 . There's no room to not have a medic and/or support in any game with 3 or more people playing, since you'll end up facing waves of critters that will tear 1/4 of your health off of you at a time.  If you pull together as a team, and watch out for each other, you can roll over most anything. Hoarding cash is frowned upon, since you can only hold so much, and throwing cash out to put more tools in the hands of your teammates can only help you in the long run. Watching each other's backs becomes much more effective than simply focusing on your fronts.  Overall, it's a really well put together game, and a must for anyone who enjoys 'let's all cling togther' type action/survival games. It's got a pretty decent modding/mapmaking community, too, and that's really helped the game last for as long as it has.

You team up with 5 friends and try and survive 4 to 10 waves (depending on server settings) of 100+ Zeds (not zombies) that continuously spawn all around the map. There are 9 different types of zeds (excluding the boss - which is fought on the last wave) and each zed has their own way/weapon of choise for killing you and your teammates, and a couple are VERY dangerous and VERY tough to kill. There are 7 different classes to choose from - all with their own special abilities, strengths, and weaknesses - and an ♥♥♥ load of weapons to choose from. I definitely recommend this game! Very fun!

Combining zombie coop FPS with elements of a RPG, this game will retain your interest in an addictive and abusive relationship. The maps and environments are well-developed, which is crucial for such a title: from the cliche zombie office environment to an experimental laboratory hidden in a dark and dank forest. The varied environments will force you and your team to behave differently and use different tactics--are you inside, or are you outside? Do you have enough space to use that grenade launcher without gibbing yourself, or for those husks to kite your samurai banzai into oblivion?  The different zombie types compliment each other well, and some counter human perks. A sharpshooter is not going to deal with crawler and general 'garbage' zombie pests as well as they can 1HKO a scrake.  It's an excellent title that still receives developer attention and content updates, and the community is still alive and slicing for a unique coop experience you won't find easily.

I've been playing Killing Floor for years and it is without a doubt one of my favourite games here.  + The combat and carnage is unparalleled: explosions, dismemberment, and headshots look and sound great + The class and perk system is incredibly robust: classes have unique roles, pros/cons, levelling is addictive + Huge variety of weapons and maps adds a ton of replayability + Best free seasonal updates of any game out there  Fair warning, this is a skill-based game and it is difficult. Newcomers should start on Normal difficulty to learn the ropes and have fun. Playing on Suicidal and Hell On Earth requires a lot of experience, working as a team, and in-depth knowledge of game mechanics. For many people however - myself included - this is the real draw of the game. If you put in the time, playing on HoE with 5 other experienced players all working together is some of the most fun you can have online. There is also nothing more exhilarating than being the last one alive on Wave 10 knowing your entire team is watching and relying on you to stay alive.  Highly recommended.

This is probably the best FPS Co-op game I have ever played. In it you level up your classes/perks to level 6 for the best advantages. You can be a Berserker, Commando, Medic, Sharpshooter, Balistics, Fire user, or Support class/perk(Not al exact names). All the perks can use any weapon that the character can afford and has unlocked or bought as a DLC. For example, the Berserker gets bonuses with melea weapons, but can use an ak-47 if he/she wants to. You can also pick different character skins to give your character some customization. In this game you either play solo or with other people online in a map that the group chooses. You must survive each wave against different types of creatures. At the end there is a powerful boss. After the tenth wave always comes the boss of the round, who naturally can endure a ton of bullets. After finishing him the round's over and the players normally can vote for which map comes up next. Also one can choose between some perks, which give boni for certain weapons. With them also come tasks, which need to be done in order to get the perk to its next level and thus resulting in better effects. There are 5 difficulties in total I think. It really ranges from ♥♥♥♥♥ to overkill, so you have a good chance to progress steadily. Also the game's still played by a lot of people, despite Killing Floor 2 being out and doing a good job of catching up to the standards of this one. So if you have some money to spare you can invest in this neat little zombie Coop FPS, it will be worth your while.

TL;DR: SHUT UP AND TAKE ALL MY DOSH! Veredict: If it's on sale BUY IT. But you may be better off waiting for the sequel that is improving on the weak points of the game.  Calling this game a ripoff of L4D is a gross mistake. L4D is a rush from point A to point B. It's fun, but it's a lineal no brainer. Killing floor is a lot more challenging. You can't run. You have to stand your ground until the wave ends. You have to play as a team, otherwise you are ♥♥♥♥ed.  You have a variety of weapons and classes- or perks- to choose from, you have to be careful about what you are doing in. Sharpshooters are mostly useless in the twisty corridors of Office, Demolitions blow themselves up there. Likewise, the melee class Berzerker is outclassed in open spaces where he can be flanked and surrounded.  And when the sh!t hits the fan, and it will eventually, all you can do is make a strategic retreat, shooting everything in your way to make your escape and run in circles while you kill the horde with precition attacks.  When you play on the harder difficulty settings it's one of the most frustrating but also rewarding games ever. Nothing can take away the satisfaction of blowing the final boss to hell in the Hell on Earth difficulty.  GOOD FEATURES: Epic slowmo 'I'M RELOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOADIIIIIIIIING' DOSH! GRAB IT WHILE IT'S HOT Classes to choose from and level up. B!TCH SLAPPINGLY HARD: The enemies are stronger and more numerous the more players are in the server. A chicken man firing a machine gun. Lots and lots of community maps that download really fast.  BAD FEATURES: Grinding. Lots of grinding to level up. Whiny casual players that quit because they can't handle dying. Noobs that join high difficulty servers with low levels and then die, leaving you with more and stronger enemies because of the dynamic difficulty. Subpar and OP meleee system. A good zerker can wipe everything given a lot of time.

A very simple co-op horde shooter with surprising depth and replayability. The premise is pretty simple; bad stuff happened at a biotech lab somewhere in the UK and you've got to fight them, the story doesn't actually matter except to explain why you're fighting what you're fighting where you're fighting them, though. The vanilla game consists of several waves of a set number of enemies (Zeds), the composition of these waves increases with difficulty as you go along, and the game also scales in difficulty (number of enemies and their health) depending on the number of players and, of course, the difficulty you set. Generally speaking you can finish a Normal round with a disorganised team of randoms, but by the time you get to Hell on Earth you'll need a well-rounded team who know what they're doing, so there's a lot more to the game - in an 'emergent', sort-of-exploity kind of way; things like how hitboxes aren't synced to clients so you can't always get a headshot by aiming for the head or how if you jump and look down while shooting certain enemies at point blank range the bullets can hit more than once, thereby saving you ammo - than you'd ever figure out for yourself.  All in all, if you have a group of people to play with, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this. If you don't and you just want to play with randoms, you probably won't ever experience the game at its hardest. The community, like many others, is a mixture of people who will accept new players and try to teach them and others who will kick low level players on sight. Which, honestly, is kind of justified; low level players physically cannot keep up with anything harder than Normal difficulty.

British currancy simulator is where you run about London England throwing money or 'Dosh' as it is more commonly known, at blokes where they in turn throw it either back at you, or other blokes who, in turn, throw it. It is a little known fact to anybody but the people who live there, but this is an accurate representation on how Englands economy works, and stock markets function as a whole. Should one ever run out of 'Dosh' it is less a crisis as a plesant trip to the local pub, which usually entails the aquisition of the nearest firearm, some sort of knife-like object, and a welding torch. Should none of these items be readily available to you, the next best option would be to put a paper bag over your head and lie down while you await the end of the world. For the rest of them who weren't just carved out of wood earlier that morning, you simply use your knife and or firearm and off one or two zombies* and you'll be back on your way to the market. *Caution: May contain zombies.  10/10

Killing Floor is a cooperative survival shooter where you and up to other five other players fight against wave after wave of genetically modified, humanoid 'specimens' that have escaped the laboratory and are rapidly overrunning England.   Gameplay is simple. Slaughter a batch of specimens, buy new equipment from the trader, and repeat until you have a boss fight with 'The Patriarch,' a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with a rocket launcher, a chain gun, and the ability to go invisible. 'Pray and spray' is worthless on higher difficulty levels, and ammo is often sparse. To survive the intense and often claustrophobic firefights, you must coordinate with your teammates and make good use of the environment, welding shut doors to create temporary choke points, forcing the creatures to destroy them before comes and eat your face. Furthermore, you need to try and complete each round near the trader, who moves her shop between waves and opens for business for only less than a minute.  You can choose one of six perks that enhance your skills in certain areas and work like classes. For instance, field medics are faster at healing, commandos do more damage with the assault rifle. Regardless of which one you're playing at the time, you'll gain experience toward leveling up your perks every time you act appropriately ingame.

Killing Floor is a fun (co-op) survival FPS that's pretty much a mix of Counter Strike: Source and Left 4 Dead. Survive waves of enemies, buy weapons every round, kill the final boss, and level-up your preferred class(es). At first glance Killing Floor looks like a standard 1st person shooter. You'll find a great many casual players who treat it as such. However, Killing Floor is designed in such a way to allow intricate co-op play. The various perks in the game allow a player to become more skilled using specific sets of weapons. Each perk is designed to have specific functions within the game. There are lots of games that claim to be co-op but Killing Floor demands that each player do their job and that overall you work with a team you can trust. Get a team together and have fun!  Update: Even with the sequel out there is still something special and unique about KF1.

Killing Floor originally started out in 2005 as a free mod for Unreal Tournament 2004. Back then, it was a buggy mess. But after not hearing much about the game, Tripwire pulled the same thing they did with Red Orchestra by releasing it, 100% polished, as a standalone game. Killing Floor pins you and a group of people (unless you solo) against waves and waves of different types of zombies. From the starter Clots, to the obnoxious Siren and to the pants-defecating-inducing Fleshpound, Killing Floor keeps you on the edge while still creating a sense of joking around with the over the top British voices demanding for LOADSAMONEY and other goofy phrases. There is a story behind the game, but I don't even think Tripwire themselves even care about it anymore (none of the character packs involve special military operatives like the original 4 default characters). It's a fun indie title that I personally think gets you more enjoyment than Left 4 Dead does, although it plays much differently.

The weapons range from duel pistols to a LAW rocket launcher, Flame throwers to a .50 cal Sniper Rifle...and some insane ideas that just make it silly...but in a good way.   Levels are well made with the environment changing from a wecked ocean freighter to the streets of london to a secret forest research lab and a deralict asylum used for rave parties, there is something new to see in every map.  a MUST for any gamer who is thinking of getting this game! I bought this game after playing Call of Duty Zombies and I was looking for a different kind of challenge when shooting at zombies. One of my friend told me 'killing floor is probably one of the best Zombie games out there and it is cheap, and very addictive'. Little did I know, he was absolutely right.  Tons of achievements to unlock, perks to level, guns to buy and, OH HECK the game is f****** difficult! I love a good challenge and Killing floor delivers on that.  A must for Zombie lovers!  -------------------------------------------------------------- Single Player: 7/10 It is fun to play alone to train your spamming skills on Zeds. Nothing beats multiplayer though. Multiplayer: 10/10 One of the best Survival Horror out there. Tons of guns, 9 different types of zombies with an epic boss and up to 6 players in the same server. Use your perks wisely and kill them Zeds like there is no tomorrow! Graphics: 6/10 First installment of Killing Floor was based off a mod. Textures could be better, I give it a respectable grade because of guts and gore. Community: 8/10 Good players, HUGE workshop, tons of items --------------------------------------------------------------

A short survival horror game that can easily relate to the COD zombies franchise but if it were an indepepdent game. The focus on teamwork is not extremely highlighted though but more of a subtle reminder that you should help each other thus all helpful intentions have to come from the players themselves. The various weapons are nothing to special except a few exceptions but the weapons aren't specifically binded to one class as one would expec from a normal class based FPS. Overall I'd give it a B- for having an intense feel to it watching all your fellow team mates at the hands of a chaingun wielding maniac. Some mechanics of the game are a bit flawed however such as reload animations not playing, guns not wanting to reload at all, and some weapons not being able to be purchased even when all conditions are meet. Average visuals for its time but deliver the content nonetheless. The various specimen designs are unique in how they function and how they appear leaving the player with a satisfied feeling when they are brought down. The main drawback I've found is how downright difficult it is to host a server. Still that might just be me. For $20 however this game is worth it for its replayability and leveling system. If you're not a fan of repeitive gameplay then this is not for you.

The developers constantly fix things when they come to their attention, add new stuff on a regular basis and paid DLC are only character skins. Beware of any cut versions though.  Edit: there are also weapon packs now - which for the most part are weapon skins, so you have two options of buying essentially the same gun for the same price at the trader during gameplay, but some of the weapons in the weapon packs fill a niche spot in between other options (-> you wouldn't normally buy them, so they aren't needed in any way).

I don't get it. I don't understand.  I played about 30 minutes of this game and found it to be the worst game I've ever played. Yet the Positive Reviews have people playing it for 2,000 hours and saying it's awesome. Even the Negative Reviews seem silly - talking about not being able to 'kill floors' and the title being misleading...  When I started my co-op game.... A horde of monsters shambled straight towards me. I fired my gun and killed some of them... But they keep coming and not approaching in an interesting way... They just shamble directly towards you.... And you kill them - and they take a lot of shots to kill. Eventually you can buy more ammo.. And then you do the same again - monsters shamble towards you and you shoot them over and over.  There seemed to be no story. No point. Nothing interesting.  Just some sort of target practice simulator. I'm in my 30's, I've been playing games for years. I'm done with games like this. I'm looking to be involved in the game and the storyline and the choices - so the rise of RPG games has been a good thing in my opinion.  Killing Floor, however, is a truly awful game...  I don't get it. I don't understand....

Super Mario 3D Land is a platform game in the Mario series developed by Nintendo EAD Tokyo for the Nintendo 3DS. The game was released in Japan on November 3, 2011, in North America on November 13, 2011, in Europe on November 18, 2011, and in Australia on November 24, 2011. It was announced at Nintendo's Keynote Conference during the 2011 Game Developers Conference held in San Francisco. The game is unique from other Mario games as it combines elements from both classic 2D side-scrolling Mario games and modern free-roaming 3D Mario games. The game was released to commercial and critical acclaim, and has sold over 5 million copies worldwide as of January 2012, making it the current best-selling game for the 3DS and the fastest-selling Mario handheld game in history.

Don't get me wrong this is a very enjoyable game. I purchased it while it was on sale, and have played it a couple of times. The guns and perks are exciting, and the zombies fun to kill, but it something seems to be dragging this game down.  The Community  Not long into my session of KF, I decided it was time for some multplayer, I found a server with normal difficulty, and devided to jump in. Now, having only played this game for a couple of hours, I was not that great at KF. I figured online play would give me a chance to get help from other players, and learn to play the game effectively. This was not the case. I was subject to abuse the second I joined! Being called names and racial slurs is not how a community should behave. I tried 4 others servers with similar resulsts.  All in all, this game is fun, btu the play base can easily turn newbies away from what could be an exciting and enjoyable experience.

If you're a fan of 'horde'-type shooters, you'll love the hell out of this. Join a match, camp a corner, shoot all the zombies, visit the shop to buy items, rinse and repeat a thousand times over. That's pretty much all there is to Killing Floor.  Pea-shooter guns. Washed-out graphics. A community that gravitates towards extreme uptightness. Unappealingly drab maps. Boring gunplay and wonky secondary mechanics. The upside is that Killing Floor still has a large and active fanbase, so there's that.

Killing Floor grew from amateur modification of Unreal Tournament 2004. Therefore to speak about loan of ideas at Left 4 Dead it isn't necessary – founders of game developed the concept of the command zombie shooter. Last year they addressed in Tripwire Interactive studio with the offer to include their creation in quality fashion in Red Orchestra shooter: Ostfront 41-45. However the management of the company considered Killing Floor rather perspective for transformation into independent game. But personally game didn't impress me. (This my opinion and it can not coincide with yours).

I think the devs overstepped a mark with this game. 'Pikey' is used as a random insult by the *player*. No other game has the actual player say a racist word to demean people. No not even GTA. It's a big deal word, it's usage in the UK is very common and its worse than the N bomb word. The P word insults Irish and Roma travelers as it paints them as poor, sub working class criminals. The use/choice of the word has malice intent no matter how flippantly it is used.  I respect that fiction can go where it likes, but when the fiction puts words in the players mouth that essentially encourages casual racism I think an unspoken boundary has been crossed.

I have to say I'm really confused. Killing Floor offers very little compared to most games. You just get the regular survival or objective mode and that's it; and that's IF it works. After downloading this game I instantly had problems downloading kbs. That's not with an M....that's not with a G. Kilobytes. Basically the smallest download in todays standards. I sat and watched in disbelief as the percentage literally went up at a fraction of a percent every 2 seconds. I tried getting help from the forums and some helpful people posted some solutions. I looked at all these solutions and thought 'There's no way I'm spending a good hour or more trying to fix a game that shouldn't have this problem in the first place'. So I verified the integrity a couple times and tried again. It worked. I thought I'd give it another try today so I did. It did the same thing it did yesterday all over again.   For the play time I had it was okay....but it offered so little. This game came out in 2009. It's 5 years old now and the developers have a broken game with in game advertising and little to nothing to do and the game has overwhelmingly positive feedback? I don't know what's more sad....5 year veteran developers too incompetent to polish their game or the players overhyping such a dull experience. Don't get me wrong; I'm sure when it came out it really was top of the line. But again, 5 years has passed and there's a lot they could've added and fixed. I hope Killing Floor 2 will be much more polished and fun. But I cannot recommend this game.

This is probably one of the better 'zombie' games out there. Buy the game whenever it is on sale. If its not on sale, buy it anyway. This is one of those games where being a lone wolf will get you killed, believe me I've done lots of times and as the levels progress, you soon realize it pays to stay with the group. On top of that, there's a good variety of 'zombies' in the game and they manage to sneak up behind you no matter how good you are. I think a lot of the fun lies in the weapons and classes. I main a sharpshooter myself and its always fun being able to headshot 'zombies' with my trusty crossbow. Like something out of The Walking Dead. Also a lot of the DLC is totally worth it. Makes for even more fun killing the creepy crawlies.
