It's plane, simple, and fun. There aren’t a whole lot of bells whistles when it comes to Killing Floor. It’s just you, 5 other people, and a boatload of zombies. The game doesn’t try to bore the player with backstory or cut scenes. It is just a down-to-the-bone wave based shooter. Some may think these are negative qualities, but it just makes for a great game to pick up and play for a little with some friends.  It takes itself just serious enough without drying everything out. All the characters' dialoged lines are hilarious, easy to quote phrases that give the game its charm, but it is still a serious and difficult game.  The community and developers are great. This may sound crazy but I pretty much only play this game during the holiday events in December. They update the game so all the enemies are reskinned to be Christmas themed. There are also holiday levels and remixed Christmas music. It just shows that the developers behind this game aren’t trying to make you cry or uncover truths about society; it's just an extremely fun and unique game that will that will give you hours of entertainment.  Also the game is pretty challenging, they offer difficulties ranging from beginner to Hell on earth, yet I still can get destroyed on medium without any hesitation. Start low and work your way up, I can guarantee that you will have a great time.

Killing Floor is a wave-based zombie survival shooter that takes place in a post-zombie-apocalypse United Kingdom. After some shady government experiments with cloning technology went awry, the CEO of the company behind the experiments, Horzine Industries, went berserk, letting his experiments loose on the world as some form of revenge. That's about as far as the game's story goes, though. It's basically just 'There's zombies here, kill 'em'.  The setup of the game is simple: Specimens (or zeds, if you prefer) attack in waves. Once all the zeds in a wave have been killed, you get a short, one-minute break in which the trader will open her store, where you can spend the money you earn from killing zeds to buy better guns as well as useful equipment like body armor and grenades. It goes beyond just buying bigger guns, though. Killing Floor offers you a selection of seven different classes to choose from, each with their own specific roles and abilities. If you choose the commando, you'll have access to a variety of assault rifles which are excellent for wiping out groups of lesser specimens, but you won't have access to heavy weapons like explosives which are good for denting larger, more threatening specimens. All the different classes complement each other well and even though the community may say otherwise, none of the classes feel flat out better than the others; each has their pros and cons.  In addition to the base classes' abilities, fulfilling certain requirements will increase a particular class's level, improving the bonuses you receive as well as giving you discounts for that class's weapons (as long as you're playing as that class, of course). Leveling your classes is important as well because Killing Floor offers five different difficulty levels. A level 2 support specialist is basically dead meat on the highest difficulty, but raising your support specialist's level to 6, the maximum, will vastly improve your chances of survival.  This does, however, create a small problem, which is if you level all your classes to the max, you'll find lower difficulty servers to be boringly easy because you're so powerful compared to your enemies, essentially preventing you from playing on those servers unles you want a very boring experience. It also is a bit of a problem since a player with multiple classes maxed out has an advantage over another player who, for instance, has only maxed out one class, just by virtue of being able to fill multiple roles throughout a match. This isn't a game breaking issue, but something I figured was worth mentioning.  More importantly, though; how does the game play? To put it simply: Fantastically. The different classes' abilities all complement each other very well. Nobody really feels like a one-man-army (unless they're insanely good); everyone has to depend on each other for survival. The guns feel absolutely brilliant, with great sound and visual effects. Despite there being only 10 distinct enemy types, they all add their own flavor of challenge to the game. Crawlers nip at your heels and attack in swarms, gorefasts charge you with reckless abandon, and the towering fleshpound will live up to his namesake. Everybody's role is important, and you almost never feel like dead weight (unless you're a low level joining a high difficulty server *wink wink*).  I should also talk about the in-game dialogue. This game is well aware of the fact that it takes place in the U.K. and announces it loud and proud. Through voice commands, you'll get to hear plenty of clever quips and unforgettable one-liners. Hearing another player shout, 'You're all fur coat, no knickers, ♥♥♥♥♥es!', is something that never gets old. While the characters themselves don't have distinct personalities, there are quite a few to choose from, especially if you drop a few bucks for some of the skin packs. Who knew a business man wearing a gas mask, a cop in a chicken suit, and a covert operative with an advanced suit of armor would make such a good group?  All in all, what Killing Floor lacks in other departments, it more than makes up for with its simplistic yet addictive gameplay. Killing Floor has received numerous free content updates since its initial launch back in 2009, and is still going strong even 5 years later. Would I recommend this game? Absolutely.

The best FPS zombie-survival co-op game hands down(until KF2!). Sorry L4D, actual strategy and enjoyably challenging gameplay makes this game genuinely intense and rewarding; and the replay value made it the best money I've ever spent on Steam. I believe I bought it for $10 on a flash sale, but this game is priceless. Player-made custom maps extend playability by a lot, and most maps were whitelisted so Perk progress can be made on them. Perk-leveling is a slow process, but each level adds invaluable advantages, especially at 5 and 6. As for multiplayer, the KF community is like most online mosh pits: an assortment of team-players... and guys who drop you for teenage 'lulz', just like any other online community. Solo-play isn't where the game shines, but it is viable in some situations; such as finishing a wave of zeds as the last man standing, and solo-play as a Berserker in particular can help split zeds up.  In short: Grab this game if you're a team-player mature enough to learn zed mechanics(KF-wiki); if not, there's always CoD, RUST, and DAYZ.

Killing floor is nothing short of excellence.  For a game that simply involves killing waves of undead enemies, it is immensely fun. The leveling up of particular classes requires time and plenty of kills but once achieved, the rewards are great. Discounted weapons to be able to buy them at earlier waves; more damage for when you want to up the difficulty (biiig difference when this happens); and different benefits depending on the class. It is a particularly fun co-op game (almost impossible on single player at harder difficulties, some achievement if you do complete it) because you need to work as a team to take down the hoards of enemies heading towards your group of survivors. Welding doors to make a kill corridor or just to buy you some time adds to the suspense in the game and is a great feature.  All in all, this game makes for a brilliant, fun, 'just kill em all' game. The only thing I could criticise (and this is actually just a funny point) would be the trader... When she moves to a different location, you can still see her standing in the old trade shop and she likes to run so far away that you struggle to buy anything in time unless you head there before the end of the wave... So much for that hold off spot you wanted to get back to ha! I highly recommend this game to anybody who wants to blast zombies to bits and do it with friends for extra fun.

While many term it to be a zombie survival they aren't your typical zombies; rather they're more along the lines of experiments. You're set onto a map where you typically fight off 10 waves of these creations and then face the boss. A typical map will take you 30-45 minutes to finish. This means it's a highly repetitive game but with a few different ways to play it in terms of perks (class) which gives a boost to specific types of weapons. It can be enjoyable when tinkering around with mutators and mods provided you're not dead set on a having a serious game. The only real goal you have is with the achievements and with maxxing your perks out to level 6 where if you really push it can be done in as little as two or three weeks. Vee's review: Version 2.0  Killing Floor is an action packed Co-Operative FPS game.  You shoot Zom-... I mean various Specimens, each with a unique ability of their own, and each with better (and worse) ways to take them out. From the simple Clot that will grab you, to the massive Fleshpound that will pound you into fine dust, if enraged.  What's good: It is a healthy challenge on higher difficulties, where tactics and teamwork are essential for the group's survival. With a proper team, you'll be having fun, and a challenge. That is bound to keep players playing the game. You have various classes for various roles, so there is a role for everyone out there.  What's bad: Class levels. They take a long time to level up, and the game is unplayable on the highest difficulties without them. Hitbox sync is also an issue, but once you look into some guides on hitboxes, it is a non-issue. Also, avoid the Objective mode, it isn't worth it.  In conclusion, this is a solid game, which will offer it's best to the players that truly stick with it. It is good from the get go, but brilliant later on. DLCs are entirely optional and not required for success. You don't have much reason not to get the core game.

'Everything is so simple when you have a rocket launcher for an arm!'  Killing Floor is nothing like it was when it was first released; so most reviews you read will be pointless now. While first released with only 5 maps, the game now has 20 total. The free content that has been released for this game is extraordinary. I would even go so far as to compare Tripwire to what Valve has done for TF2, tons of free, great, content. The only snag is the gameplay itself. Some may find it repetitive, while others will find it an enjoyable experience. I have 110+ hours in the game myself, and find this game well worth your money.  I do have to say that the game does go on sale for $10 fairly often so I would wait for a sale on this one. Don't get me wrong, it's a great game, but it isn't one you need to play right now.
Killing Floor is always a good time. I've been playing it on and off for about two years and the basic gunplay is simple but fun. It just never gets old popping zombies heads off, does it?

A well made, team focused, zombie killing first-person shooter for up to 6 players per game unmodded. Contains very little story, but is good for hundreds to, for some, thousands of hours of gameplay with its multiple difficulties and perk levelling system (Do something enough times and you'll get bonuses to it). After a certain point, the difficulties change more than just health and damage, making certain difficulties much different than the last. Has a fairly large online community with practically no griefers, and receives free content updates every few months. All for just $20.

If killin' zombies is wrong, than I don't want to be right!  Hella fun co-op (online and LAN) squad game that puts you and 5 friends against the tide of the superpowered undead. Job perks give you bonuses to certain weapons and allow you to specialize in your prefered method of killing, too.

Open-ended zombie survival. You decide where on the map to hold out and try to balance out the 7 different perks amongst he players. You level each perks, which gives an addicting feature to keep you playing, but medic is an absolute pain in the ♥♥♥ to level. Five different difficulty levels all of which require players to stick together. Voice communication is basically mandatory on the newly added difficulty level. While the core gameplay is repetitive, the leveling aspect of the game and sandbox map design makes it entertaining for many hours of play time.

Killing Floor is a simple game. It won't wow you with a deep narrative or revolutionary gameplay. You shoot zombie-like things called 'specimens' created by an evil medical corporation known as umbr- er. Horizine. Anyway, it's not a criticizm that its premise is so overdone because really, in this specific execution, it's not.  Expanding on that idea, Killing Floor's focus is gameplay, and you can expect all the bells and whistles of other FPS. Just. Shinier. Polished. If it were a cake, it'd be gunporn flavored and the icing would be neat but predictable AI behavior. On paper it's easy to strategize and complete a map on even the hardest difficulty. In reality, something always goes wrong. Even after hundreds of hours, the game still plays like a somewhat campy horror movie. The community is generally pretty good, it's still strong and its sequel is on the horizine. If you don't have this, get it. Just know that it has a load of DLC, some of which offers weapons you can't get otherwise (but will see other players use.) Can use a steam emote here? :shivahstar:  But really. Good game. I always fall back on it when I have nothing else to play. A lot of my friends do too. Never have trouble getting a full server of competent players. But then, we got into it before the semetic dlc. It helps that it runs well on toasters.

A great game! A team of 6 people fighting off 7 or 10 waves of specimens, each wave harder than the last with new monsters added on nearly every one of them. After clearing wave 7 or 10 (short game/long game) you'll face the Patriarch aka the boss...hardest enemy ever, but nothing a few well placed pipebombs and a good team won't take care of :D also this game has a class/perk system. Every perk has a number of things you need to do, and once the numbers are met the perk levels up granting you better abilities, more damage or on the final levels a better gun to start with or some body armor. It might not be perfect for your tastebuds but I seriously recommend at least giving it a try :P

If i were to recommend a game that's wave-based, shoot-em-up with twenty-five or more guns that you use efficently against armies of failed experiments that give you bounty cash when you kill them, so you can kill that in horrifically more brutal ways with better guns, as they slowly upgrade their army with bigger baddies until you fight an all-mighty boss that could rekt you without blinking, i'd recommend Killing Floor. Seriously, this game is my TOP FAVORITE, just because of how enjoyable it is. Yes, it may be old, and yes, it's not graphically impressive, but it's a damn good game. It has me STILL playing, even after hitting rank six with every class and gaining every annoying-♥♥♥ achievement. Why do i keep playing? Because it's fun, and because my friends have it. Playing by yourself on Hell on Earth, doesn't compare to the simple mayhem of playing with 6, or 64 other players (depending on what player-based mods are installed.) And, if you don't like the original ZEDS, you can re-mold them with extremely well-done mods like the Killing Floor: Dead Space mod, or the Aliens mod, to fight more horrific creatures. Hell, they even have mods to make the game ALMOST likle DOOM. Theres weapon mods, character re-skins, maps, VEHICLES, and so many other amazing things. This game gets a 10/10, no matter how people string the BS. It's a great game, and has some amazing re-play value when you're trying new things out. Multiplayer is fun, single player is fun, and PLEASE don't say that popping a ZED's head of with a M99 ISN'T satisfying. Because if you did, i'd call you a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ liar.   Roses are Red, Violets are Blue, I got the game. You should too.  Enjoy!

Killing Floor is a very well made wave shooter game. I have actually lost an entire night's sleep almost completely because of this game, and for good reason. It's kind of like if Left 4 Dead was made entirely out of the special zombies, and added a few more. The zombies also feel more memorable and dangerous than the Left 4 Dead zombies because they synergy better together in order to achieve the goal of eating you alive. Each and every zombie type adds a certain strategy to the game, some run, some are bullet sponges, some do AOE's, and some are just ♥♥♥♥ing invincible. It's a hard game, and you kind of need to do Co-op for difficulties above normal, and don't worry if you're like me and usually don't like online, the multiplayer is actually pretty good. The only complaint I have about the game is there are almost no mods that you can get that don't disable perk progression for the round. Even a map that you like a lot and isn't totally cheaty won't help you level. But other than that it's a great game.
If you love killing a variety of creatures for long games, this is the one for you. Tripwire Interactive keeps the game updated as well. But watch out, there is a monster awaiting if you can survive.

Killing Floor is a great zombie FPS and a good co-op game. It focuses more on wave-based arcade shooting rather than survival, though the goal is to survive a preset amount of waves.  There are quite a few good pros to this game. First off, there is the variety. There is a huge variety of weapons bundled with the game. On top of that, there are somewhat overpriced DLC weapon packs. However, the weapons feel decent, and the gun handling is rather smooth. Now on to the maps. There are plenty of maps bundled with the game. Not enough? Get the Toy Master mod. Not enough? Check out the Steam Workshop. The possibilities are endless. On top of that, I believe there are some extra weapons on the Steam Workshop. Grab five friends, and prepare for hours of fun for anyone.   Remember that no game is perfect and there are some downsides even to the amazing Killing Floor. The gunplay, though decent, does feel rather rigid. Also, graphics are not top-notch, but remember the age of the game. Also, as previously stated, the weapon packs are rather pricy. Also, the game is rather boring when you take it on solo. It will give you some hours of enjoyment, but it WILL get boring. That is why I have low hours on this game. It is BORING in solo. If you want a blast in solo, I suggest something else.  FINAL SCORE: 92/100  CONCLUSION A good team-based run-and-gun zombie survival game.

Why does everybody like this game? I really don't understand it, this game is terrible. The gameplay is repetitive and boring but the most annoying thing in this game is the slow walking. You move like an old grandmother! An old grandmother with one leg! And a doggy attached to her leg! This game should be called 'Walk-like-a-granny-and-her-doggy-simulator'! I never experienced anything this slow in my life. Playing The Stanley Parabel after this game feels like playing Burnout. I pressed the s***t out of my 'W'-button to get, by any chance, just a little bit faster than this 0,003 miles/hour! I almost punched a hole in my desk while pressing the walk-button as hard as I could. I have muscle ache in my finger every time I play this game. I even tried to find a cheat to go faster (it works with the negative weight-trick, but it takes so much effort to do it every time)! I can feel my life passing by when I move. No, seriously, I feel my hair and my fingernails grow, I feel getting wrinkles in my skin and my bones getting brittle when I play Killing Floor. This game sucks out your life. But guess what - there is actually a button to go even slower...serious. No joke. I'm not kidding. This is for the real sadistic players who want to experience the full load of perpetuity in slowmo-hell. It's like a neverending commercial for shampoo where a beautiful lady shakes her voluminous hair to smooth jazzmusic. But just without the lady and the smooth jazz. Imagine just this slowmo-loop. And you're in it. That's Killing Floor. Why...why, oh why did you do that, beloved developers? Is this supposed to be fun? Well, It isn't!  Ah yeah, and the difficulty...wow. 'Easy' is really easy, but never think about changing it to 'normal', because then you will suffer a tragic death in minutes, because these stupid Clots grab you and you have no chance of getting away. Sure you can train to get better and master the normal difficulty, but there are so many better games out there (and faster as well) so I choose another one instead.  But ther is actually one nice thing in this game: the weapon desing. The weapons are really cool and fun, if the developers would just had invested a little bit more time in the gameplay than just the weapon-designs.

Short review. Killing floor has without doubt done it right, but of course there are some flaws ^^ :)  pros - It works perfectly and smoothly, and the grafics is nice - the mobs works great and good variation - lots of weapons, of course some of them are quite useless(but luckily only a few) - the perk system is great with its variations.  cons - the perk leveling up is a pain in the **** , of course you should use some time to level up, but it takes a looooot of time, no fun in that... - It is probably not really the game itself, but often in co-op people tend to camp, which means that you will likely use 90% of the time to sit on the same spot and hit the enymies in one directions. Of course the game developer has tried to remove this flaw by moving the trader around on the map, but yeah it often becomes dull very quickly.

I've been playing this game for a long time, ever since the back in 2009 when I tried it out over a free weekend. Shortly after I decided to buy the game for obvious reasons.   I've been revisiting the game for pretty much every holiday update toghether with my friends and I've always had an amazing time. I've never taken the game too serious and always kept it at a casual level. But lately, since none of my casual friends play it anymore, I decided to take it up a notch and actually learn about the game and its mecanichs. And for the first time I suddenly realized why some people have up to 3-4k hours in this game.  There's a whole world of techniques and setups you can use to clear a level, the complexity of this game is beyond of what you can see at a first glance. Of course it doesn't have the skill cap of a game like, let's say CS:GO, but it's not as far behind as some people may think.  I've played this game nonstop these couple days and I will keep going for a while, and hopefully get more knowledge about the game so I can take down the Suicidal/Hell on Earth difficulties on a more frequent notice.  An absolutely amazing game, which I hope will keep getting updates sometime after Killing Floor 2 is out of early access, because it certinaly deserves to live on.

What can I say about Killing Floor? It is probably the greatest Infected/Zombie game I have ever played. You and up to a team of 6 players(Custom servers can have up to 99 players in one game) battle through 22 different maps, not including custom-made ones, with 10 waves of infestation ranging from the weak but suprisingly annoying Clot at Wave 1, through to Fleshpounds, Skrakes, Husks, Crawlers, Sirens, Bloats, Gorefasts and Stalkers, all the way to the finale with the Patriarch - a guy with a chaingun on one arm and a rocket launcher on the other and an alien-like device coming out of his chest! This game is predominatly multiplayer as it can get quite lonley wandering the streets with a shotgun looking for infected. To make this game even better, there are 7 perks(Field Medic, Beserker, Firebug, Sharpshooter, Support Specialist, Commando and Demolition) which take a while to level up to Level 6 but it is totally worth it! Finally, there are many, many achievements which is FAB!

This was one my first PC games, back in 2010, when i first entered Steam. I got it on a Sale and, for a time, Killing Floor was the only game i was able to play on my old Intel onboard graphic card. I made many friends playing this game and had hundreds of hours of fun. Now, almost 6 years later, KF is still one of the best co op games i've ever played in my life. It's not a hard game to get good at, playing with other people or by yourself, there's a great variety of modded content along with the official stuff released through the years by Tripwire. The hardware requirements are, of course, not really high, and although the graphics can look quite outdated, this doesn't stop all the fun the game can provide.

In a nutshell, this game is worth every penny. At first impressions, the game seemed mediocre, mainly that the fact it is an expansion of a MOD in a previouse title.   The graphics and voice acting would be considered to be inferior in comparison to more modern games of it's genre, but what it lacks in aesthetics and storyline. It more than makes up for it in gameplay. In comparison to L4D2, I found this game to be much more emersive and kept me on the edge of my seat as I massacre through wave after waves of 'specimens'. Unlike L4D2 its is not rigid in it's gameplay forcing you to be purely team reliant however it allows flexibility in playing style as you have variety of 'perks' ranging from demolitionist to a medic (7 different perks in total), thus you are able to run around like a headless chicken carrying a sword. In all, it is a brilliant game that will grow on you and the quirky voice acting has left a real trade mark on this game, I LOVE IT (I killed over 70 hrs playing this)

This is a great game to get some friends together and take down some genetically engineered horrors. Killing Floor being kind of a mixed bag with bits from different genres like Counter-Strike and Left 4 Dead and maybe an RPG, you and your friends strive to survive wave upon wave of 'Zeds' of differing varieties. Fortifying areas by welding doors closed, collecting money along the way to buy new weapons, armor, ammo and killing baddies to raise your status on one of several 'perks' you choose until the final battle with the Matriarch. There are even varying difficulties and map times to challenge your team in this ultimate battle to survive. Totally a game worth having in your collection.

This game shouldn't even need a recommendation; it's simply something that should be on any first-person shooter player's list. Rock-solid gunplay, a good variety of enemies, a trend of teamwork without insta-gibbing lone wolves, and moddable support makes this a zombie shooter that's easily on-par with L4D2. With admittedly aging graphics and not as much depth in the non-modded game, it does have to be let out that this game isn't for every single person playing computer games out there, but the minor flaws in Killing Floor are completely covered up by everything they got right, and the continued developer support (as of the start of 2014) acts as the unneeded icing on the cake.

There is no other way to put it: If you do not buy this game, whether for the full twenty dollar price or while it's on sale, you are missing out. I've owned it since release and still find it fresh and challenging (especially with each new, free update) and have gotten several friends into it as well. Buy it.

This one snuck up on me. I bought it on sale figuring I'd play it once in a while at a LAN party or something. But once I started playing it hooked me pretty quick. There is something really satisfying about all the weapons, and upgrading your perks really adds to your combat effectiveness. Using iron sights is essential and firing 'from the hip' with no on-screen aimpoint adds an additional challenge but when you get good at it you feel pretty badass. Teamplay is essential and I love that 6 people can play instead of just 2 or 4 like most co-op games. Gameplay is relatively simple (fight off waves of monsters with a boss at the end) but the levels are large and well designed. Strategy consists of finding a holdout spot with fallbacks (if possible) and channeling the zombies into your killzone. Public games actually work well too. This game is very different from Left 4 Dead 1&2 in a good way. I highly recommend.

This is a fun , creepy and dark game. It is a very under rated game that never got the attention that it deserved and should be bought for people who love coop and shooting mutated humans in the face. This game can very well be mistaken as a zombie game , and at first I thought the very same thing. Nope, they are mutated crazy people that there goal is to kill your crew that is supported up to 6 players on a normal server. Once you are in the game you start out with a pistol and a knife. After each round you go to a shop that sells and takes weapons. Your currency is what buys you these things you need to survive. Your currency is in pounds instead of dollars for you American players like myself. The enemies get harder every round. At the end of round 10 you have to fight a boss that at times can be very frustrating but with a team can be vaporized. The only complaint I have is that some servers have insanley hard enemies when it says normal, thankfully these servers are scarce and are not very hard to avoid. Overall I give this game a 9/10 this game that may be similar to left 4 dead is a good coop game that deserves our attention as well as its sequeal coming up who knows when.

Rating: 5/5 'Do not hesitate in buying this FPS. You will not be disappointed.'  If you're looking for a good all-around zombie-killing game, definitely take a pause to check this game out. It's filled with all the basics, including flamethrowers, pistols, sniper weapons, explosives, rockets...and if you're like me, you'll definitely appreciate the added medic-gun, which provides basic self-defense and a team-healing alternative fire. Killing Floor does not boast the best graphics, and lacks a real story...but it was intended to be a game one can just jump right into, and when you take into account the active fanbase, it leaves very little room to be disappointed. So if you're in favor or at least impartial to mindless zombie torture, give this game a shot...HEADSHOT! Haha!

This is a really fun addictive game. it's basic focus is playing with friends, although playing with yourself is just as fun. but instead of me blabbering on about how i love it, here are the facts   The Good:  -very fun to play with friends, especially the way killing floor encourages teamwork through borrowing money and better healing on teammates  -the perk progression system acts like a class system where if you do a certain thing or goal, your basic abilities are increased, thus making that class more deadly. possibly the best feature of this is that you do not have to be that class to level up. such as if your a commando and you get pistol headshots, you can still level up sharpshooter which does not limit your ability to upgrade and thus making you feel more freedom like.  -the variety of monsters is great, offering zoombies that are invisible, agile, angry, BLOATy and even some that have weapons, and most that have special and deadly abilities to take you and your team down.  -the map variety is great as well, offering some maps at day and night, some in different weather conditions, and some in bizarre areas like a moonbase and santas workshop. overall map variety is great, and is increased by Steam Workshop downloads that can give you extra maps from great creators.  -as i said the multiplayer is fun. but that is not all, the connection is also great regardless that this game was made in 2009, the servers still stand up to a total of 6 players which is astonishing. the most amount of Ping i recieved was 90.  -the character variety is also excellent. there are many to choose from, each has good detailing and have clever phrases which play out on your zombie killing debochery.  -the weapon variety and feel of them is excellent as well. between games like BF3 and CoD, this game surprisingly has a better and more realistic feel to them. having them shake your screen, a nice muzzle flash, and satisfying sound. the weapons are excellently designed, especially compared to big budget titles.  - the graphics, while not the best today, are very good. even if you do not have a gaming computer you will be able to play this game. with very minimum requirements, this game will run smooth on any pc, as long as it is not from 2005. hell, that might even work. while you can run easy on low and medium, the real quality is shown in high and very high. it is astonishing the amount of detail the textures can have in a game like this. not once did i experince texture pop ins during my playthrough, and if i did, i did not notice them. the only thing i can ask for in this department is a larger FoV. but who cares?    Now that we have all that awesomeness out of the way, time for some not so awesomeness that may make people hate killing floor, despite its great gameplay:  The Bad:  -the story is terrible. why? i never had it clearly explained to me. i had to go to wikipedia to find it out. although the story that wikipedia explains sounds very good, it merely serves as an excuse for killing floor to have zombies running rampant. personally i like the wikipedia explanation of the story and i am interested in the myhtos so it would have been cool to include a story mode to explain it a bit. talking about modes...  -so about the modes. first i think i should explain that, even though the perk system is a big and great part of the game, you cannot progress your perks with other modes other than the original mode... let that soak in a little bit. you can only progress your perks in the original mode that you play. if you want to set up a custom game in sandbox mode you cannot progress your perks. i personally love the sandbox mode which allows you to customize almost all game features, but without perk progression, you are less motivated to play sandbox mode for fear that all your progress will be for not. another thing that disables perk progression are Mutators. mutators are things that enable special rules such as only a certain type of enemy or no buying weapons, kind of like paintball mode in goldeneye. this was not a big issue for me, but may affect other people.   -another issue i have with the game is the character portraits. simply put they are terrible. they are low resolution, big, and usually come in a shade of grey and red. while the character models look good, just press portrait and you will see my issue.  -probably the biggest issue i have with this game is difficulty. so prepare for a long one. i will break it up into sections. here we go: 1)Difficulty settings: while the beginning difficulty is fine, Medium is way too hard. killing floor comes with varying difficulty levels. Beginning, Medium, Hard, Hell on Earth, and Suicidal. beginning is fine, normal average difficulty, nice pace. then you go to Medium and there is a huge difficulty spike. the enemies are harder, they come fster and more numerous. it was steps above what it should have been as i expected medium to be the difficulty any average joe shooter player could play on. the issue i have with hard is exactly the opposite. it is just like medium. infact, at times, i found hard easier than medium. the other difficulties are fine considering their scale. 2)enemy difficulty: so let me explain, there are many specimens, each with varied specialties. but there is one so overpowered it's not even funny. and that is the fleshpound. when you attack him, he rushes you and does massive damage. like, kill you in 3 hits damage. yea... now usually i do not have a problem with this, in fact i encourage a good challenge to test my strength in gameplay such as the Big Daddy in bioshock. the issue i have is that if the fleshpound is so hard, then why are the rest so easy? you have your average one hit kill enemies such as crawlers and clots, but then you have husks which shoot rocket launchers, scrakes which chase you with a chainsaw, and sirens which blur your visions with screams. the three i consider to be heavy hitters are the husk, scrake, and fleshpound while the sirens are more like supporters of them. but the husk and scrake are nowhere as hard as the fleshpound. the scrake is more appropriate so i guess my gripe is with the husk. yes he has a launcher but why so weak? his launcher would encourage you to snipe him, but with his health you could use one katana swipe. also a note considered, the Flesjpound has about 1/3 of the health of the patriarch (last wave boss), so that speaks essays about how powerful he can be. i do not think the fleshpound should be weakend, i think the other should be strengthened.  -now to my last point, and that is with weapons. first of all, some weapons should not even be in the game. such as the m99 sniper rifle. sure its crazy powerful, the last sniper you can buy, but with a price of $3000 its hard to get especially considering that EACH BULLET IS $500! yes, you heard that right. making this rifle worthless on anything but beginning difficulty. one more thing is unlockable weapons as well. the Dwarfs?! Axe can be unlocked by playing the dwarfs free2play game a bit and get gold which i did and that was fine. my issue is with the ZED gun. now a while ago, there was an event where you could collect parts of this gun which is no longer available making the weapon being there pointless beyond the update! i searched and scrounged only to realize i would have to downgrade my game to get the gun. its not a big issue though.   so now you can gather your opinion about the game from my statements and hopefully others. watch some gameplays and see how the game works. it released in 2009, so its pretty damn good for a game back then, and even now. personally you should not think about buying it, and if you are get it now. at a full retail price, it is totally worth it. or you can save your money for the confirmed killing floor 2. but enough with rumors. overall i give this game, considering it released in 2009, a 8.5/10. it is a must buy.

Killing floor is a game where you are dropped in the middle and forced to defend yourself against an onslaught of 'zeds'. I would say that if you mixed Nation Red with Left 4 Dead, Killing Floor is what you would get. You can have six people play at once online, the levels are well made and dont feel too linear and the gunplay/ melee is a blast. You go through waves (from four to ten) then at the end you fight a boss.  There are perks you can get but unlike other games, perks serve more as a role than a buff. For example, the berserker is great with melee weapons and damage resistance but if you want to blow something up you will get a better 'boom' with the demolition perk.   This game does have its down sides. Sometimes the game will troll you with certain zed spawns and the hit boxes can be a little funky at times. But aside from that, its very addictive and a blast to play with friends.

6 Player Co-op Wave Based Horde Mode has never been better! Come to jolly old England...But bring your guns. An experiment gone bad has released H.O.B.O.D. (Humaniform Organisms Bent On ly on Devouring) (NOT OFFICIAL DESCRIPTION) into the streets of our once verdant green. Come and shoot them all in the faceholes, using the best ballistics in any current game (with the POSSIBLE exception of the ARMA series). There's a Persistent Rank system for each of the separate classes (Sniper, Assault, Shotgun, Flame, Explosives, Melee, Medic), and as you rank up, you get perks and cheaper Class-focussed weapons at the Trader. You can change classes at the end of any wave, no weapon is restricted, assuming you have the carrying capacity and moneh to spare. Tripwire has been supporting this game for over 2 years, STILL releasing new weapons, maps, enemies, events, skins, and even classes. They also chose to make ONLY character skins are Pay DLC; every other piece of game content is free to all.

Have you ever wondered what it would be like to face waves of genetically engineered zombies with your friends, all while specializing in certain skills and moving from trader to trader? Well my friend you have an oddly specific tastes, and your day has arrived. It appears that the folks at Tripwire Interactive have heard your crys and brought this divine fire down from Mt. Olympus. Give it a try!
Yeah, one in each hand!

With so much gore, carnage, and replayability what's not to love about this zombie shooter? There's a levelable class system that encourages different playstyles depending on if you wanna slice em, shoot em, explode em, or just watch em burn. The free seasonal updates are an added bonus that helps keep the game feeling fresh. Keep in mind that this is indeed an FPS and requires quick reaction time and thinking for those times the zombies just seem too much. There are different difficulties to ease beginners into the game while giving the veteran players a challenge the further they progress through the game.

I find this game very entertainng. People may bash it for the simplicity, and lack of single player. But the ammount of support for mods make for a fresh experience. The gunplay is pretty satisfying, with very nice limb dismemberment and headshots. Theres an active effect called 'ZED TIME' when the game thinks you did something cool, for example, a single bullet penetrating threw 3 or 4 heads. When 'ZED TIME' kicks in, everything gets slow-motion, and you have extream accurecy with very little threat, (Your aimer moves quickly but the zombies do not.) Its got a very tacticle feel to it, Where you get money for each wave of zombies you survive. Then the traded opens for a few moments, you can restock on armor, gernades, ammo and of corse, firearms. There is also a perk system, where doing certian tasks level your selected perk. They provide some decent class bonuses, most consisting of discounts to your specific wepond class when you buy from the trader. There is a great varity of weponds as well. Ranging from the Katana to rocket launchers and everything in-between. HOWEVER, A HUGE NEGETIVE FOR ME IS TRIPWIRE WANTS YOU TO SHELL OUT REAL CASH TO BUY WEPOND PACKS. They are nothing amazing, but if they arent anything great, why make us pay? Bad tripwire. But like i said before, the mods keep me into it, and also keep everything fresh. I personaly love the 'Gun Game' mod, pretty much modled after Call Of Duty's game type. Theres also DM, TDM, and DM Extreame, which is a deathmatch with random zombies in the mix. Theres also some other modes, but another thing that keeps this game fresh is events. Holiday or whatever, but they add new things, new unlockable characters, and reskins to all the zombies. But all in all, this game is a deffinte hit for me, and at its price point, its worth a shot to anyone intrested for sure.

Killing Floor is one of those zombie FPS's that you have to play, just to get a feel for what's out there, personally, I love it.  By far, the best feature of the game is the weapons. Beautiful. To use, to hear, to feel, to watch... Great models, nice variety, plus many more of them via the Steam Workshop, plus skins.  The enemies are relatively samey, but there is a large selection of maps, which are quite varied, but there are community made maps incase you run out.  Things have been tweaked to make things better, like the shop, it now arranges the weapons by your chosen class by default, so you actually buy the guns for your class which you will have perks for which some noobs didn't.  The leveling system is different, you can basically farm levels to give yourself a slight advantage if you want, but I much prefer being able to say; 'Purely got here from playing normal matches, no farming, all sweat, tears, pain and work.'  I'm mostly a medic, and working as a team, being pro, feels really satisfying in this game. The frequent slow-mo 'Zed Time' is sweet too. Also exploding heads is awesome.  The storyline (if you can call it that) thing is meh, personally I don't think it needed it, I see it as more of a 'there's a zombie apocalypse, get over it, lets kill some zombies!'  The voice acting in the game is probably a bit of a Marmite situation. Most of the characters voices are British, everyone is kind of Baldrick from Blackadder, with bizarre phrases like 'TWO BLOODY GREAT HANDFULS' when you dual wield pistols (which incidentally, you can aim down sights with, which is a nice feature, I love 'akimboing' as they call it in CoD - bleh) The trader is some generic flirty tomboy which mostly gets on my nerves more than anything, with her odd phrases like 'Not enough money for that one babe...' - 'Shop is open boys, come get me... ;) xoxoxooxoxoxxoxxoxxoo'. Not very zombie apocalypse, a bit ♥♥♥♥-takey. I like the sort of exaggerated British voice acting, but the lines they say are a bit on the lame side.  What I would change, in a sequel maybe, is probably add a few more types of enemy, just for the hell of it, possibly some more game modes (Like I love the whole L4D2 being a zombie thing, that's awesome), and make some of the maps and textures a bit brighter, and make the whole UI a bit more 2014 instead of 2005, but that's not a massive deal really. To top it off incredibly high res textures and some destruction physics like destructible maps, whop PhysX in there with that too and we've got probably the best zombie FPS ever made. Also add some music.  However, where it currently stands, I award it 91/100 or 4.5 stars / 5.  If they make a KF2 with all my changes, I would buy it. Full price. Pre-order.

Killing Floor is a game that lives up to it's name, as the sole purpose of the game is to kill zombies (aka Zeds). To help you take down wave after wave of zombies, there is a nice enough arsenal of lethal weapons and (hopefully) your teammates. The game boasts a variety of different enemies, ranging from 'the common footsoldier' to almost tank-like zombies which can take and deal incredible amounts of damage. However, perks are available which enable you to choose the best possible strategy to counter this. All in all it's an incredibly straightforward game, but it's hugely fun to play simply because it's such a no-nonsense straightforward game, but being quite a difficult game at the same time (depending on the quality of your teammates).

However, yhere's a lot of heads exploding here and a lot of gore, so don't buy it for your 8-year-old.  Be aware, this is a multiplayer-only game, and sometimes it's hard to find servers, since each server can only host up to 6 players. If Team Fortress 2 is light-hearted, brightly coloured, fast paced PvP perfection with beautiful (hilariously ridiculous?) bells (hats?) on then Killing Floor is the flipside of it's FPS coin. In my view these are THE two shooters every PC gamer should have in their collection. Up there with Left 4 Dead 2 as THE definitive multi-player zombie shooter, Killing Floor adds persistent character leveling and is the perfect 'survival' alternative to L4D2's excellent 'journey' based gameplay approach. If you're looking for a serious, grown-up, spine tingling, and ultimately superb co-op zombie survival shooter then this is most certainly your game.

My first recommendation was too short and the second was too long, so let's give this another shot: Six-player zombie co-op survival. Lots of excellent, satisfying guns with great variety and feel, tied to player perks which level up to give you something to work for, making your favorite guns more effective and bringing more powerful ones more within your reach. Also other kinds of less gun-ish weapons like flamethrowers and swords and explosions. You'd expect the old zombie survival shtick to wear thin after a while, but somehow there's always just enough variety to keep it fun and engaging. Admittedly I was not sold on the game at first, but it gets better as you get more involved. Does have some bugs which are rarely fixed in an expedient fashion. Bottom line: Not perfect, but hours of fun.

DOSH! Grab it while you can, lads.  Okay, bad way to start off a recommendation, but whatever. If you haven't played this game yet, it's essentially a game dedicated entirely to Horde Mode. Fight waves upon waves of different types of specimen (stop calling them zombies, if you have been calling them zombies), until you come across the almighty 'father' of these creatures, the Patriarch. Rinse and repeat on another map.  What helps make each match different would be how everyone else plays, as there are multiple perks (classes) to choose from in the game. The more you play as these perks, the better the stats for those perks become. But be prepared to do a lot of grinding to even level up. It's not so bad in the early levels, but as you rank higher, it requires more to get to the next level. The best way to explain that is with this example: You're a level 3 Commando, and you just inflicted a total amount of 1.5 million damage with assault rifles. Congrats, but you haven't killed 2000? Stalkers, so you don't get to rank up until you kill more Stalkers. If you play the game casually like I do, it's going to feel like forever until you get into the higher levels, as a head's up. I'll let you be the judge on whether or not that kind of leveling system is good or not.  If you haven't heard yet, this game is famous (or imfamous) for its dialogue. It's so bad, but in a good way. Think of it as like a cheesy B-movie of sorts. Considering that this is an independent game and has the feeling of a B-movie anyways, I think this is okay. Even I come back to quoting some stuff, from time to time.  One thing I especially need to mention is that this game is heavily supported by the community, in terms of custom maps, mods, and even dedicated servers. Don't believe me? Check out the Steam Workshop for this game, and you'll see how big the community's support for the game is.  Oh yeah, did I mention this game is essentially Horde Mode? Yep, only game mode, so if you're not a fan of it, don't play this game. However, if you're alright with it, I recommend playing this game with friends. This game is meant to be for a group of six people, so you know what to do. Killing Floor is permeated by a sense that you're having way more fun that you ought to be. It's absurd and crass, and yet you can't help but enjoy it. Whatever the reason, Killing Floor will have you gleefully decapitating monsters like the reincarnation of an ancient war god.

Killing Floor, the name says it all. Wave after wave of carnage. If you've played LFD or LFD2 then you have an idea as to what you're facing here. Zombies are more than just that. You've got your basic melees, you've got wall crawlers and stealthers, not to mention bloaters with acidic vomit, Pounders that act like tanks and beat the crap out of you. Don't forget the Husks which set you on fire with their attached fire laucnher weapons and finally. When you finish every single wave you get met by the Patriarch; the biggest bad ♥♥♥ of em all. He stealths, he has a Rocket Launcher, Mini Gun AND his augmentations allow growths in his body to snap out like a Xenomorph and rip your head clean off in a single hit.   Start racking up those kills, level those classes and stock up on Ammo, Grenades, Guns and Body Armor. You're gonna need it.

I absolutely love this game because it's creative, legitimately scary, and satisfying all at the same time.  ...this wave-based FPS is filled to the brim with unique maps, gore, and zombies just waiting to be obliterated. I will start off by saying that you will either play this game for hundreds of hours, or not at all. People who fall in between are the minority.  Ever play the Nazi Zombie minigame in Call of Duty: World at War or Black Ops? Now imagine a full sized version of that with a huge selection of official maps on top of the many more user created maps on top of that complete with classes, a shop to purchase weapons between rounds, boss fights, multiple types of enemies and more!  Recently updated yet again over a year and a half after release, this game is second only to TF2 in terms of official updates. With 132 achievements and perks that take awhile to level up, there's always plenty to do here. And people actually co-operate when you play on the harder difficulties (usually)!  Long story short, if you enjoyed Nazi Zombies this will suck away so much of your time. Totally worth the price of admission.

A great co-op FPS a little akin to Left 4 dead, but with less of an emphasis on run and gun. Instead the game focuses more on classes and finding a tactical location to hole up in for the duration of the round. The classes feel nice and varied and the only way you'll get anywhere is by having at least one of your friends dedicated to the medic position, and sticking together with at least one other person as you traverse the multitude of fun and dark horror levels. There are generally ten waves of increasingly difficult enemy types to fight through. before facing off against the ultimate zombie badass, the Patriarch. Overall, an awesome game to spend a few hours on with your buds.

A somewhat clunky and incredibly difficult shooter that will really grow on you if you give it a chance. Rather than linear level gameplay like the L4D series, KF presents a wave survival format and open maps with far more challenging and deadly zombies to go up against. Add to that the need to level your class skills, the importance of team composition, the lack of UI crosshairs (you need to aim with the guns actual sights), and you get one heck of a challenging but rewarding game experience. The learning curve is huge and starting at level 0 you will die a lot (even max level people die alot), but it's worth it as the game is really fun and challenging once you really learn it.  Not a great game if you prefer to solo though, so keep that in mind; you need to play this online (there are plenty of servers out there). Also a great game for achievement fans as this game has a huge array of achievements to try and earn.

Well I'm actually pretty new to the game and this is my first review but here goes! I've never been a fan of these types of 'tower defence' games.I consider this one because of the fact that monster come at you at waves and to win you must wipe them out,etc. However,this game made me rethink about my opinion about them.Perhaps it's too damn well made!Or perhaps I just find it FUN to use a crossbow and double-big-♥♥♥-pistols to splatter the brains of a horde of 50 zombies coming at me. The catch, however is - if you make a mistake ( allow one of the weakest, but most annoying buggers in the game to grab you ) , you die.Except if you have the right perks,which I will now explain. Perks define your weapons and bonuses.Technically they are classes.There is a pyro,grenadier,sharpshooter (technically made to one shot most zombies using headshots),commando which is kinda heavy weapons,medic and support specialist.Best thing is - you can always switch them!To level a perk requires one or more feats. (Example : To level up a medic you must heal N points.To level up a sharpshooter you must do N headshots.Each perk or class has its own unique feats and weapons.) You have to wait a round, however, and you can change perks once per round,during the shopping time.Shopping time is the time between rounds,lasts a minute and there's a predefined spot on the map,the location of which is shown by an arrow in the top left corner of the screen, and a red sort-of misty-light that show you the way after the round has ended.One in the shop, you heal automatically, restock on ammo, get new weapons and if you want to, switch perks. Depending on the size of your team, the difficulty level and the match length, the zombie numbers range from 20 to 70,in a 10 match duration in Normal solo mode,where you can hone your skills,and 50 to 200 if you have 5 or more teammates, this time in Normal Multiplayer. Difficulty level is what it should be - measures the damage,health and general smarts of the zombies. Moving onto the zombies, there are 12 or so kinds of them, ranging from small black spider-like zombies to the Boss, the Patriarch,who has a minigun, rocket launcher, claws, invisibility and when he's close to death, he has 3 health syringes which heal him.He uses 1 syringe per heal. All in all,there are minor bugs that aren't even close to serious, and are mildly annoying.The game is extremely fun to play, especially with friends.It's also set in Britain so expect lots of British slang. Now hurry up, you lot, and buy this bloody game while it's on sale!

Awesome FPS with cool classes, perks, many weapons and all kinds of enemies with unique abilities and weapons of their own. Nothing is ever certain in this game and an easy run can just as easily turn into a bloody mess out of a horror movie. If you're just starting out, trust me - you don't want to get caught. The maps are quite difficult to finish for unexperienced players and total annihilation is not that uncommon. It definitely pays off to level up the classes because when things get tough, class perks might just save your life. Some people get annoyed by the occasional slow-mo time that is triggered for all players ingame, but it never bothered me. Running around dressed as a giant zombie-killing chicken with a crossbow is just too much fun.

Playing this game is quite literally a 'Bloody good time'. If you are a fan of any of the popular zombie games using Valve's Source engines (No More Room in Hell, Left 4 Dead 1/2, Zombie Panic! Source, for example) and need a little more gruesomeness with a bunch of quirky british mercs (who all suprisingly sound a lot like Harold Lott), I wouldn't even hesitate to recommend this game to you. As I said before, you'll have a 'Bloody good time' playing this game. I guarantee it.

I have always been a huge fan of horror survival games. I was massively involved in the CoD Zombies community for a long time. When I first saw my favorite YouTubers struggling to get through this game, I was greatly intrigued. So, I waited for a trial weekend to come along, and sure enough, it satisfied every one of my desires: a fast paced, frantic shooter similar to LFD or CoD Zombies; good graphics, even for such an old game; a large assortment of weapons; difficult boss fights and frightening encounters; and a mob mentality meant to devour you. This has pushed my limits on multiple occasions now, and I am quite certain that KF is one of the best survival shooters out there right now. Looking forward to the next one!

The overall rating for this game is a blatant lie. It's unbelievable that a game like Killing Floor could rack up an 'overwhelmingly positive' review. They all share the same insipid scenario and objective (fight waves of monsters, kill the final boss, repeat).  The base game is a waste of money. Purchasing DLC for this game is unjustifiable.  PLEASE AVOID THIS GAME!

Based on an old mod for UT2k4, this game is by no means trying to ride the wave of L4D's success but rather paving it's own way into the Survival Horror genre. You will find yourself battling varied hordes of experiments with up to 5 friends (Total: 6 :) ) with an epic boss battle at the end. This is by far one of the best games to play with friends. It's survival shooting at it's finest! The game also has a massive community so it's never hard to find a game and if the base game is getting boring for you there's plenty of special modded servers to add some spice. Basically if you like Left 4 Dead or pretty much any survival shooting game get Killing Floor, it's worth your time and money.

This game is incredible. It is a little short on features compared to some other shooters however that doesn't stop it from being fun. It's a simple concept, survive waves of zomebies (called 'specimen') and go shopping for bigger guns and more ammo in between rounds. It's great, simple fun and can be a blast for a very long time. The constant addition of maps from the developer and the community keeps the game fresh as well as the newer game mode in which there is actually a mission to perform.  In summary it's definitely not a complex game but it is definitely a good one. Plus it's almost always on every major Steam sale for $5 so there's really no reason to not pick this one up.

It's bloody. It's dark. It's freaking fun.  Killing Floor was a bit of an adjustment for me. The levels are dark, the slow-mo headshot effect is a learning curve, and it's kinda scary when you're the last person left in your squad; but once you get used to it, it's a great game. If you enjoy head-exploding blood-splattering survival combat, this is a game you would definitely enjoy.

-Core Review-  Gameplay . 6 (with friends 8) average = 7 Music . 8 Art . 7 (outdated) Mechanics . 6 (outdated)  Total . 7   -Nice Words-  Killing floor is a fine game if you want to grab some friends and kill thousands of mutants. The music is very intense and surprisingly fitting to the game itself. Art style is a little old now, considering the game itself is a little old now. However it is perfectly fine for what the game is. Mechanics are old, the engine is old, the game is old, old old old. YES it's old, but good! mm back to mechanics, yes they are old, yet it is extremely satisfying to blow mutants heads off, or chop their limbs off in slow-mo. Over-all it is a great game to play with your buddies. I would recommend it to anyone who likes gore, and killing lots of things in short amounts of time.  Still, get it on sale.   -Personal Experience-  I had just gotten out of playing L4D2 for a while and I was in the mood for another zombie-like shoot em up. So naturally when my friend Michael suggested this game to me, I hopped on board very quickly. Not knowing what to do was half the fun, and exploring about the game, learning the different maps and different perks was an experience on its own. For the first 20 or so hours I never even fought the boss, but when I did, man I was not ready.  When the first of the events started that was a real blast and every event after that was something nice to come back to and try to complete. Now however I'm running out of custom maps to play and events to do. The workshop addition is nice, organized way of offering skins and maps, but I am definitely more excited for the release of Killing Floor 2.  This game has grown more of a classic to me now, after so many hours of playing, I occasionally go back to play it, and it never disappoints. All I hope is that Killing Floor 2 will be better than this game, from what I've seen it looks like it will be the same stuff over again, with updated mechanics and (slightly) upgraded graphics. In which case, I will not be playing it.   **= Old Review =**  This game is siiiick, grab a buddy (maybe a beer) and shoot some zombie ♥♥♥. Not the complete best graphic/movement wise, but this game is a MUST GET. Remember its boring alone, get a friend to play too!  Kick ♥♥♥ game, 4.5 Stars!

One of the best co-op game Tripwire Interactive has to offer.  A survival horror game with waves and waves of ZEDs to defeat followed by a final boss in the last wave. The ZEDs have quite a few variations, from weak Clots to powerful Fleshpounds; and the final boss, Patriarch.  Every player has access to every perk and weapon, with certain perks providing boosts to specific weapon types, such as the Berserker perk boosting melee weapons and the Sharpshooter perk boosting sniper rifles and pistols. The weapons available for purchase are also not limited to what perk you are using and as such players are allowed to mix around their perks and weapons to be used against the waves of ZEDs, allowing player customization.  Even with the age of this game, Tripwire has provided great support for this game and has released a lot of DLCs and holiday themed maps for players to mess around with. If that's not enough, there is also the Steam Workshop, where players can download custom weapons and maps to play with.  Overall this game is just wonderful and it is worth every cent. Pick it up with a few friends and you'll have a blast. Or if you prefer to solo, that is also an option.

I cannot explain how much I usually dispise Survival Co-Op. But this game is absolutelty brilliant in so many ways! Unique classes with strong upsides that make every class stand out against another one. Need someone bulky? Play a Berseker. Want to be stationary and need to wield doors? Play a Support Specialist. You are even 'forced' to stick to your role in your team, since you get Level-Ups for the stuff your class is supposed to do. Snipers need to headshot mutants, Medics need to heal etc. and since you get permanent stat bonuses, as well as a starting weapon in higher levels, you want to do that! This is a first class Co-Op shooter that shouldn't be missed out by any gamer that has a little brains to go along with a abit of aim.

A great 1st person shooter, 6 player coop, gorefest shootemup. Killing floor allows for player progression, some GREAT teamwork, and a lot of really tense moments.   Replayability is the name of the game here. Since it's just 6 players vs. wave after wave of monsters, you'll be doing the same thing over and over again. The fun comes in trying to beat the matches with less-than-perfect teams. It would have been interesting to see an AI director like in L4D2 increase or decrease the difficulty on the fly as you played, but this is an old MOD with a lot of charm. Disclaimer: Well, let's first start with, the following isn't an April fools joke.  The game 'Killing Floor' isn't your average Zombie game. If you don't think about the depth and deep thought put into the game, sure, it is a normal zombie game. You shoot, get weapons, and shoot more stuff. This isn't Killing Floor. So first thing that makes it different from others is the vast array of weapons and items. First of all, there are multiple classes for all weapons. They could also mix classes and weapons. So lets say, you enjoy explosives, but you like the commando's ability. So you could be a commando and use pipe bombs(Just large explosives that deal alot of damage). The second is the amount of maps. Call of Duty Black Ops 2, a popular, widely-known game, has a zombie mode with 3 small maps. Killing Floor has (without any Steam workshop downloads) has ~27 maps. A plus side is, they are enormous. You can play multiplayer with your friend and stick by their side, next thing you know, you guys are completely seprerated and have no clue to each others locations. The thrid and final reason why this game stands out and is fantastic is the different zombies. There is a zombie called a stalker which is invisable until it hits you. A crawler which goes fast, and crawls making it hurt. In conclusion, This game isn't 'Terrible' nor 'Average' or even 'good'. In the end, if you think about everything put into it, Killing Floor is 'extraordinary'. Thank you for your time.

Killing Floor is always fun to play with friends (or to make new friends) and offers a challenge. Work as a Team and prevail or work by yourself in the squad and perish.  + Great Teamwork game. + Can be scary at times (whether you're the only one left alive or there's a couple of fleshpounds in the hallway). + Challenging boss. + Interesting Brit accents (I'm Brit)   - I found the music funny at the time I was listening to it (I no longer listen to it however) since I was into death metal at the time but the music doesn't really fit into the game, it's just 'noise' that prevents you from hearing stealthier enemies. - There's a lot of player harassment in this game (lots of blocking paths/wielding doors) as well as beggars. - There's not a lot of humour in this and the humour is often very limited in itself thus making it annoying after a while.

Really fun game to play. I mean, what is there that is better than decapitating zombie-like monsters with a crappy pistol that lasts you all the way until the End-of-Match boss?  Nothing. That's what.  The game is great. With pubs being able to work effectively in a team without even communicating and just sensing when someone is in trouble. I mean, of course you need to give them a hint every now and then, but most of the time it's like Spidey Sense. They just know. And so do you. Like magic...  Combat is fun but can get repetetive after a while and because of that I might recommend some people to take breaks from this game. After all it is just shooting things, blowing things up and slicing things. It can get boring after a little while, but not so boring that it would make you want to get a refund.  The game runs pretty well on an Nvidia GTX 560ti which is pretty outdated (but heck, I can run The Witcher 3 on high setting with this) but it can run well on max settings due to the game also being outdated.  Community is great with a massive variety of custom maps and mods for those maps that offer a large variety of gameplay. People often play on those servers but quite a few also play on standard ones too as loading into the custom servers can take a big chunk of time due to all of the custom textures and files and stuff.   TL;DR  Overall, this game is great for friends and strangers alike, although I think more people have flocked over to KF2,  however , there are still a lot of people playing this game for it's nostalgiac things.  Give it a play. It's great fun.

FPS zombie wave arcadey game - sort of like Nazi Zombies, Killing Floor has a great set of monsters (called Specimens) and an impressive array of weaponary. The fun gets even better when you consider the large modding community who fire out custom specimens, weapons and maps. KF runs on the Unreal2004 engine, but the modellers and texture artists have done a good job at bringing the best out of this older engine - as consequence however, it will run well on older computers. For those of you who hate grimey textures? Ouch, I would probably stay away from KF, as the art style kinda integrates grime into everything - check a screenshot or video first. You get to pick from a list of classes that specialises in either tasks (like welding doors, healing, etc.) or weaponary.  TLDR; Think medical-experiment rather than zombie FPS on a wave arcade setup with classes. Not for haters of grime/dirty textures.

Killing Floor is a hilarious point and click adventure game for puzzle lovers. The player takes upon the role of an asthmatic vegetarian wolf studying to become a genie. In the course of his adventures the player will encounter a large cast of famous funny characters and solve sixty different puzzles. Six neuroscientist designed highly replayable brain training exercises will earn the player precious hints to help solve the more difficult puzzles.

This is a simple game with just one gamemode, but that is enough to keep you hooked for hours. You will start as rank 1 in the beginning but will slowly progress your rank as your play, each rank of each perk grants you more benefits to help you fight against the Zeds. Don't expect to play on the highest difficulty 'Hell on Earth' when you just started, you will die within seconds. This progression is keeps you coming back for more, you will feel a sense of satisfaction when you finally advance to the final tier of one of your perks. But that don't mean the game will be any easier if you fight alone, its best played with friends who can watch your back. If you enjoy killing zombies with friends, I'd totally recommend this game.
